As a complete novice to the whole comic book subculture (I realise I am a traitor to my generation), I think it would be unjust for me to do a lone review on this film. If you are like me and have almost no grasp of the complexities that make up the genre, Watchmen comes across as explicit, over the top, self reflective, under acted and far too long.

However, as a fan, it is likely you will have a completely different slant. According to my very close friend and movie companion (no, not the same as the chick-flick partner from last week) the film genuinely captures the essence of DC comics multilayered adult comic themes. Essentially recreating the world of head spinning art, societal anarchy and satirical campiness as dictated in the original novel.

Watchmen is set in an alternate 1980's America in which costumed superheros have been exposed and outlawed, the doomsday clock which charts the cold war tension between USA and the Soviet Union is permanently set minutes away from human annihilation and tricky-dicky President Nixon is has been re-elected for a third term in office. 

The scene is set when the graphic murder of The Comedian (Jeffrey Dean Morgan) reverberates through the remaining superhero community. Rorschach (Jackie Earle Haley) a washed-up clinically insane but no less determined masked vigilante becomes obsessed with exposing the truth behind the unusual circumstances of the Comedians demise.

Uncovering a conspiracy to discredit all past and present superheros, Rorschach pays a warning visit his former crime-fighting legion. Starting with reclusive techno-gadget nerd Nite Owl (Patrick Wilson) and outed hero and business tycoon Ozymandias (Matthew Goode) Rorschach's warnings are dismissed as the incoherent ranting of a madman.

Rorschach in his plight then visits the only superhero with any real power Dr Manhattan (Billy Crudup). A scientist whose nuclear experiment went arwy was transformed into a shape-shifting, nude, electric blue super-psychic who is rapidly losing touch with the human condition and at whim could bring about the final apocalypse.

Along with his long-time partner the lycra clad Laurie, AKA Silk Spectre II (Malin Akerman) Dr Manhattan works to find a way to recreate his omnipotent power and channel it into a never ending power source for the free world. 

As a novice, this is about the point where the film lost interest.  With the characters already established all that seemed to be left was a montage of over the top action sequences, an unnecessary sexual encounter, a scattered interplanetary storyline and decade confused timeline all being held together with underwhelming CGI and highly inappropriate song choices. (Completely destroyed the emotional tone of Hallelujah forever)

The Watchman was creatively casted. Consisting mostly of relatively unknowns that clearly have a remarkable resemblance to Hollywood headliners mirrors the feeling of the film; Almost there but not quite. Jeffrey Dean Morgan a perfect example, so close to Robert Downy Jr I actually had a heated debate with a colleague.

The colours palette is clearly taken directly from the comics, focusing on muted dark bases accented with gold and purple to highlight the significant. The bright blue used is for Dr Manhattan clearly reinforces the importance of his powers (and needlessly exposes his over exaggerated privates). 

Costuming mimics the comics with batman like rubber masks and almost painted on figure emphasizing outfits. The most unique and yet basic being Rorschach, his simple outfit of plain police inspector style clothes leads all the interest to his mask. What looks like a white hessian bag with ink blots on closer inspection is, as his character, a Rorschach (aka ink bloat test); ever changing an open to interpretation. 

The storyline, although it seams weak, does cram a remarkably high percentage of  plot points faithfully including the tiniest detail, classic panels, original dialogue and a checklist of characters into its 160 minute running time.

The way director Zack Snyder integrated the fact the movie was based on a comic book was strikingly skilful, recreating the storyboards by almost pausing a sequence mid stream so it looked like it had come straight from the comic to the screen. Even as a novice this was clearly apparent, especially in the pain scenes; quite graphic but still artful.

The Verdict: Adrenaline-seeking young men will be enthralled by Watchmen. Fans of the original books watch it with a critical eye and enjoy the culmination of one of the most acclaimed comic books in history. Non-fans, it is not light entertainment, perhaps try to be open minded... 

Published: The Queanbeyan Age
Date of Publication: 13/03/2009

Alan Moore once created a comic, so densely packed, so thematically pumped and totally rotted to the core, some deemed it unfilmable. A master piece in its own right, Watchmen was a feast for mature comic book readers, one that dipped lower than 2000 AD and went blow to blow with the likes of Frank Millers graphic novels Sin City. This work of art was marked from the get go, going through multiple stages of production, with different different writers, directors and actors, for almost a decade and when Zack Snyder decided to take on this methaphorical and hyper realistic take on a world where the Americans won Vietnam, people ultimately shrugged his pre production off as a phase. Moore's classic is set around a group of vigilantes called the Watchmen, who grow up in the shadows of their predecessors the Minute Men, who brought justice to a chaotic world. However after the accidental creation of a god Mr Manhatten, American attempt to turn him into an ultra weapon and deterant, which may win the war in Vietnam for them but changes the face of history and puts the world on the brink of a nuclear holocaust. During the countdown of the doomsday clock, a visual aid of letting the worlds governments know how close they are to all out armageddon, one of the Watchmen, The Comedian, is brutally murdered and its not long before the decommisioned group of rogues begin to dawn their masks again in order to save humanity. I've not ever scratched the surface with that over bloated synopsis and if I was to do so, I would be up for 3 weeks writing a thesis on the piece, however you can completely understand how a film adaptation was close to impossible to pull off. Now I understand there are naysayers, however for me Watchmen is a brilliant achievement in cinema and for Zack Snyder, you have to give him credit for even tackling this behemoth and managing to come out the other side with a film that makes sense and works on its own merit. Is it perfect, not at all, will it feed rabid fan boys, reasonably. Watchmen is a mixed bag and although the original cut is just shy of 3 hours, I am led to believe a longer cut has emerged with some animated additions and a plethora of more contextual scenes, but here I'm looking at the theartrical cut, it is entertaining. Zack Snyder was riding high after his successful Dawn of the Dead remake and the machismo fuelled 300, so he seemed like a viable choice, and he pulls out a pretty big arsenal of tricks here. The cast are a mixed bag, Jeffrey Dean Morgan, Jackie Earl Halie, Patrick Wilson, Malin Akerman, Billy Crudup and Matthew Goode make up what appear, at least on paper, to be a formidable ensemble. However the final result is far from the case. The positives first are of course Morgan as the diabolical Comedian, a character who is so integral to the source and the movie, that having his death in the opening 10 minutes is not only shocking but lays a wonderfully crafted insentive to set up the characters, the history and of course the tone of the film. Even after hes gone he effects everyone, constantly and with the limited time Morgan has to play with, he does a fantastic job of not only portraying the raw and disgusting side of this character but the physical aspect as well. Billy Crudup is equally spell binding, although he has a lot more to play with, his take on Manhatten is alien yet human, and he gives a whopping performance for a guy motion captured beyond recodnition. Jackie Earl Halie as Rorschach is fittingly distrubing and equally another man without a face, per say, brings a overdose of film noir and perversion that very few actors could to the role. We then have the not so great, now before going any further, I love Patrick Wilson and Matthew Goode, I think they have done some fantastic work over the years and their attempts and Night Owl and Adrian Viet are not completely shambolic, however, something within the writing and directing of these characters just seems to be mistreated. Wilson is okay as a down trodden version of Batman and Goode, is sinister enough as the smartest man on the planet but neither of them really have a chance to shine a lot, if at all during this epic and for Wilson its made even worse as he spends a good portion of the film acting beside Malin Akerman, who I'm sure is a very nice person, but here she is horribly miscast, she lacks the emotional depth and range to pull of a complex character like Silk Spectre and because of that, a lot of time, whens shes not kicking the shit out of someone or boasting her good looks, she just doesnt cut it and this of course has a knock on effect as her and Wilson are both the human gateway into the hell. So when those characters to gel and come across as almost comic relief, it really brings the film down several pegs. The writing is also a mixed bag, there are some excellent moments of dialogue and monologue that will make the hairs on the back of your neck stand tall and a huge tonne of character exposition and arcing, but equally we also find huge chunks of clunky and forced moments that just dont feel part of the universe we are in. Halie gets the best stuff to work with here, as he wanders through the night, playing detective and narrating his own take of a bile ridden existance, where as equally we are forced to endure some really ropey and forced romance from Akerman and Wilson. To the films merit, it does have a lot to say and address and it manages to convey most of it, however some fair better than others. It knocks the tone and distress bang on the head, with praise worthy apocalyptic over tones and scientific and political break through's, also taking time to investigate how being a vigilante would effect you as a person, however yet again, to often is this glossed over or treated half arsed, in favour of destruction and catastrophy. So how does the visual aspect hold up? pretty freaking well actually, all be it some of the CGI has aged but this film actually has some extremely potent and iconic imagery throughout. There are tonnes of moments that this film visually throttles the viewer and there are times when Zack Snyder goes into slow motion over drive. It works for some of the film, but there is slow motion for slow motions sake a lot and by christ does this film have one of the worst and hilarious sex scene ever committed to cinema. On the whole however, Snyder does manage to deliver and bold and entertaining film, even if its not quite what purists hoped for, however the graphic novel still exists for them, they can wash this aside if needs be. Watchmen is a mixed bag of treats, there is a lot to like here and at points its great to feel like your watching subject matter that actually matters in a comic book film, instead of Loki being all pissed off at the Avengers, it has a huge weight and depth behind it and for that its commendable, it appeals to adults, while still trying to possess something magical about the whole affair. However a handful of ropey performances, jilted dialogue and an over abundance on slow motion make this film really suffer at points. Its no Dark Knight but its a lot better than some of cinemas more recent comic book outputs.

lack of action and boring storyline.

Terrible sound balance, transparent big plot twist (anyone who has seen any Disney movie ever can probably guess who the villain turns out to be), and about as incoherent as the source material. 

If you liked the Watchmen comic and don't mind terrible sound balance, you'll probably like this movie. If, like me, you found the comic over-rated, meandering, and poorly written and despise having your ears blasted at random so you can hear the quiet parts, you'll probably be highly annoyed by it all. Filmography is competent, effects are good, could have done without the flamethrower phallic symbol (hey, director: superhero flicks use that gag because they can't get away with full-frontal nudity. You already have the R rating! Why are you doing PG rating gags?!) or the token woman trope. In all: All the ridiculousness and plot holes and casual sexism of a campy 80s-style superhero flick, without any of the charm or charisma. But well made enough that I didn't shut it off in disgust, which is why it's not a 1.

Top-notch cinematography and a stellar soundtrack make this grim, doomsday drama soar. Set in a parallel 1985 that's unquestionably unnerving, this film will find its way into your psyche. Having never read the graphic novel I went into this film blind, and was swept away in a gritty world of superheroes is never heard of before. Whilst they don't particularly stand out from one another, as an ensemble piece on good and evil it's catching. Difficult to watch at times and always thought-provoking, I feel I've discovered a real gem hidden in plain sight. I'm late to the party but I'm glad I arrived.

Grade - B
-This review is of the Director's Cut-
'Watchmen' is truly a beautiful thing to behold, with Zack Snyder really outdoing himself. It's easily his best movie to date, with a complex yet fluent narrative, great performances and an different (but awesome) soundtrack. Although its running time is far too long, the last 30 minutes are touch-and-go, and the movie has to deal with arguably too many plot points, Watchmen succeeds as both an adaptation of the graphic novel and as a movie in its own right. Definitely underrated.
Just ... don't watch it. Please.

Watchmen --This was a movie full of terrible conflicts for me. On one hand, this was possibly one of the greatest fucking movies I've ever seen. On the other hand, it was also the worst movie I'd ever seen. On the other hand, I was blazed during the entire movie, thus perverting or enhancing the entire experience, so neither conclusion is clear. 

This is one of those one hit wonders; you can watch it one time, and then you're done. Watching it more than once causes shame and severe abdominal pain. 

And yet, this is one of those movies I'll have to see again. And maybe (MAYBE) one more time. And then once more after that to appreciate all the succulent nuances permeating the entire film.

When a film opens and the photography is fucking stunning as fuck, I know something is going to happen to change the very ethos of cinematic history. This film was that.

It fucking... woke me up. :scared-shocked: 

And I don't get woken up easily.

This fucking film had a few cunts get pwned. And I mean PWNED... And that's still the least of your appetite's romantic, vicarious, slaughtering indulgences. 

There's time play. 

Yes, there's Momento. And then there's time play. I've battled more coherent cat's cradle-strewn webs of time swimming upside down on acid in the middle of orange clouds on Mars-- the time roared. It fucking had it's hand up your dress the entire night. You were seeing double before double was invented. You were feeling the impact of in medis res before the greeks and the Greats even had a chance to unroll the yet-to-be-aroused parchment. 

Fucking Time left the clock, said an eerie incantation in the form of slower than motion photography and brought itself to life in spite of its own difficult manners. 

People and events often fight each other for a foothold in what we like to refer to as chronology. People want to mean something while events could care less about the recognition and more about the simple Medal of Accuracy; as a cause of laughter, they wish to be recorded and then go unregarded.

This is the charting of maps and the beginnings of patterns. This is wooing of destinies by the calloused, potent hands of circumstance, plain, without the perfume of sentiment. 

This film paced itself, set its own course and let its pitiful 20 & 30-something crew believe it had come to see a common spectacle of mundane gladiators. And by the end of the film, no fresh green eye-shaped leaf could resist the silent tarnish brought about by the Pied Pipering voice of Autumn. We drifted together down the drain to the very end of time. And we were washed as we were washed away.

I... There were intrusive scenes of candy-coated affection. The rotting stench emanating from a sterile construction of middle class passion couldn't help but justify the eager budget concerns of those on land yelling to those at the helm, enough to put your nuts in harm's way... And "The Owl" could better be renamed "The Faggot"... These meteors alone destroy the earth underneath the nimble feet of this once-upon-a-midnight-blaze movie.

But see it once.. And then see it once more. And reel.... in the narrative. Soak....in the displacement of clocks, watches, and naive notions of recording what will stay in spite of your desire to hold it. 

Is it any coincidence that the clocks moved forward on that unassuming day in March... You be the executioner. Let the jury close its eyes instead and shed duty like a youthful obligation from the reptile's back.

I honestly can't figure out why people didn't like this movie.  From my perspective, it is an awesome achievement.  Riveting, complex, moody, compelling, completely original...  I can't find fault with it.  Highly enjoyable and satisfying off-Hollywood movie.

Great soundtrack and excellent visuals. The story is very complex and morally mixed around, which makes Watchmen stand out from other superhero films, that and the graphic violence, language, and sexual content that most other superhero films stray from to make the film more appealing to younger audiences and achieve the PG-13 rating. Rorschach was an amazing character, one of my favourite superhero portations of all time. The ending is depressing, but still satisfying. The fight scenes were heavily stylized versus realistic, making it visually appealing with many slo-mo moments but not as gritty as I wanted it to be. The pirate comic sub-plot was confusing at first, but I learned to enjoy the way it turned out. The story gets very complex at times, almost borderline confusing, I had to see this film on multiple watchings to fully understand what was going on. However, for superhero fans that want to watch something darker than Spiderman or The Dark Knight, feel free to give this film a shot. Nonethelesss, good movie.

A good movie to analyse how to adapt a graphic novel. It leaves us a lesson, which is: don`t think a great graphic novel will turn into a great movie. There are too many stories within the plot, a lot of changes in the narrative point of view, resulting in a rather confusing and epiphany lacking movie.
Hated this. So much.

Forget The Avengers and Iron Man and the what seems like hundreds of other Marvel movies and characters and franchises. Watchmen is my absolute favorite superhero movie because it's so different.

I expected the usual tedious action movie with a boring villain and story and overlong action finale. Watchmen takes the superhero genre and turns it on its head. This is a seriously made drama about the hardships of being a superhero. There are kick-ass action moments, but Zack Snyder's epic extravaganza is surprisingly more dialogue-heavy.

If you haven't read Alan Moore and Dave Gibbons' graphic novel then you might not enjoy the movie. It's an incredibly complex story with a lot of twists and turns in the end. You should see Watchmen first for its gorgeous special effects and then a second time for its story and thought-provoking themes.

Good movie.  It was a little long at exactly 3 hours - probably would have been better shaving off 30 minutes.  Loved the violence and gore.  Fight scenes were great.  Love seeing Malin Akerman get fucked (I think she's pretty damn hot).  Story was good - though it took a little while to come into shape.  Love the message/debate at the end - is it worth it to kill millions to save billions?  That was very well done.  I could have done without Dr. Manhattan's blue cock hanging out for half the film - in some scenes he had like speedos on, but then they were gone the very next scene.  Thought it was funny when he was "fucking" Akerman while working on other things - that cracked me up.

There is no way I can express how great this movie is. Zack Snyder is Ike a combination of Christopher Nolan and Michael Bay: he's a great storyteller, with a flare for high budget special effects. The accuracy grabbed me by the eyes and slapped me, because Watchmen is a long novel, and Snyder seems to be the only director who could've pulled off making the movie. What really grabbed me was Jackie Earle Haley's performance as Rorchach. Everything from his body language, his voice, his look, everything just screamed "RORCHACH" at me. He was perfect, and so is the movie. A must see, definitely.

While exciting and interesting this film completely misses the point of the greatest graphic novel. Zack Snyder was a poor choice for directing this film because like in 300, the ultra-violence is stylized, however this style doesn't work because Watchmen isn't supposed to be ultra-violent. This film could have been better if Zack had just stuck to the source material.

A film for the fans, of which I am not. Watchmen is pretty to look at, especially during the fights, but it's not that interesting, or perhaps too long. By the end of the film, I was fast-forwarding to each fight scene.

Watchmen is one of those films that has a lot of ambition from Zack Snyder that directed the remake of Dawn of the Dead and the comic book adaptation 300 before this. This got mixed reviews from critics and the audience which after watching Watchmen, I can kind of see why people didn't like it, but I still think it's a very enjoyable comic book movie. The acting is the best part from Jeffery Dean Morgan, Patrick Wilson, Malin Akerman, Billy Crudup, Matthew Goode, and especially Jackie Earle Harley with an intimidating deep voice that should've been the Batman voice that Christian Bale wanted to do, but never knew how to do it. The action scenes are really good, and the characters are very memorable. The effects are gorgeous to look at, and the opening credits are really good as it shows the history of Watchmen and its heroes. The story is really good, but I felt like there's way too much story going on and it's very complex even if the movie is 162 minutes long, and with the ultimate cut, I'm sure that it would've been fine that way that's 215 minutes long even though the studio wouldn't allow it. I'm fine with how complex the story is and not simple at all, but for some viewers, it's probably going to be too complex for them to understand to the point of not caring about the film anymore. The costumes look sweet, and the chemistry between all of the heroes are really good. The writing by David Hayter and Alex Tse is really well done that understands what Watchmen is about, and the direction by Zack Snyder is very stylish and never seem like it's enjoying itself. Watchmen is quite a superhero movie that I've never seen this dark before or new and kept me invested from beginning to end.

Right down there with Sin City under films that never should have been made, Watchmen gets all of the Nihilism of the graphic novel and none of the tongue-in-cheek humor.  Part of the mildly amusing story is that these super heroes are all old, grey and fat while Dr.  Manhattan gets less and less human with each passing year.  In the film, however, this isn't how the characters are portrayed.  Here they're in the prime of their lives and strive to take over the world in true super-villain style.  Gone are the consequences and repercussions of past mistakes that are the bedrock of Alan Moore's graphic novel, and ushered in are the sadistic torture of Roschark and the somehow #winning philosophy of Sally Saturn and Nightowl, who mutually agree that being superheroes was a stupid waste of time to begin with.

Underrated film interpretation of one of the greatest graphic novels of all time. The film stays true to the comics and portrays all of the characters very well, especially Rorschach, who's screen adaptation is nearly flawless.

Now I'm not one of those people that was a huge fan of the graphic novel, in fact I've never read it, so my opinion is not encompassing how the film measures up in its adaptation. But the film itself, in my books, is brilliant.¬†

This is the sort of superhero flick that I like to see, and there are so few of them. Films which show characters for who they are, not for the way they act, their smugness or their smarmy comebacks. The character development section which I got the most out of was of course Rorshach's, a man who turned into a vigilante riddled with hate for the human race and disgust for the world in which he lives. The way the film shows him in quest for uncompromised justice is fantastic, showing his extreme methods along with his good intentions.¬†

Nite Owl's journey, too, is great, showing a quiet, restrained man who can barely even talk to a girl without his hero suit on who is overwhelmed by the circumstances surrounding him, hating the fact that he has to take action at all. Even though, when he does, it is a sight to see; snapping people's arms in half, pounding people into concrete and causing a right ruckus.¬†

Silk Spectre's journey is slightly less shown than these two, although there is a clearly shown confused and frustrated woman who has just about had enough of a loveless relationship with both her husband and her mother, with the overwhelming comedian constantly hitting on her and the man whom she really wants in the Nite Owl.¬†

Dr. Manhattan's journey is the most central to the movie of all of them, though he is the least human and least emotional of all of them. It takes the other characters pointing out his subtle drawing away from humanity for the audience to notice it, such as when the comedian kills an innocent Vietnamese women while the Dr. watches on, but it flows seamlessly nonetheless. The strange detour to Mars is confusing to a viewer with no backstory but acceptable in terms of storyline, as he had to be away from Earth in order for the plan to go in to action.¬†

The climatic end wasn't quite as fulfilling as I'd hoped, but the film's incredible imagery, action and sequences more than make up for it, not to mention the inspired opening credits sequence. Fantastic film.¬†

Defining Scene:¬†
Rorshach finds a girl who'd been kidnapped and brings on the justice.
Very good to see if you've already read the graphic novel.

I was impressed by what the movie did as an adaption of a graphic novel. The graphic effects are perfect, and capture the action of a comic book. There are a good amount of slowmo shots and much detailed violence. There are times when I questioned whether or not a violent scene should have been shown, but I couldn't help but appreciate the vividness. The directing isn't all about violence, I can still remember the dismal cityscapes shown throughout this movie. This portrayal of a dystopian New York City gave me the feeling that although it was set in a very different world, it possessed some quality that rooted it in realism. 

The story of course grabbed my attention and kept it the entire time, and this is a considerably long movie. The acting and portrayal of Rorschach and The Comedian were amazing. I love when a delusional character is done right, and that's exactly what Rorschach is. The Comedian, a morally twisted character, kept me second-guessing what I would put past him. These guys and many other stellar characters are all tied up in the same mystery, and the movie did a great job of showing the mystery through the extreme perspective of the characters.
the best superhero movie ever made!
In my opinion its the best example of what Zack Snyder is capable of, totally painting a world. I love the thoughtful style of Watchmen, which is overlong but extremely unique.

It may be a little confusing and too complex to be appealing for some, but Watchmen is still a great film. Its visuals are impressive, its acting is outstanding, and its story questions our personal view on evil and good. Overall, Watchmen is a great film.

"Watchmen" is a film noir epic whose characters happen to be masked crimefighters. Jackie Earle Haley's Rorschach is great as the antihero narrator who helps us navigate the tangled array of clashing ideals as channelled through the main players. Snyder and his screenwriters convey these contrasts with greater complexity than those which Christopher Nolan explores in "The Dark Knight."
Dark, gripping, and beautifully realized by Scott Snyder, Watchmen is an unforgettable adaption of the outstanding graphic novel and one of the greatest comic book film's ever made.

Just how screwed up would a person need to be to be a superhero?  That's what Watchmen sets out to show us, but the wooden performances, weak casting and overly complicated story line distract from the comic's rich characters.
A "so so" adaptation, with some pacing issues.
Interesting film. I've been meaning to watch for a while, and although it wasn't all too great, it was a nice breath of fresh air from the usual movie market.
Rorschach (Jackie Earle Haley) was absolutely magnificent! He put the N in Neo Noir! The brooding and sense of dread that encapsulated him elevated the film in my eyes!

First regarded as one of the most important graphic novels ever written, later the film provided a representation that polarised its viewers. The price of peace, the nature of man, relativity of time and the fruits of evil... these are all themes discussed in "Watchmen".

I can still remember the first time I read "Watchmen" - it was a graphic novel like non-other I had seen. The questions posed, the themes explored... when it's all over, you're sitting there with a blank look on your face, trying to figure out how you would have reacted to every conflict that was presented.

When the first trailer hit, we were given a taste of the art direction, and shown how practically every shot in the film was replicated from the novel. Zack Snyder actually used the source material as his storyboards, only making minor changes, and then the occasional drastic change (mentioned below).

Alan Moore's story (paired with Syder's alternate ending) presented a fantastic narrative. I can't even begin to list off the moments of moral ambiguity, action and drama that keep you on the edge of your seat, or even just the plain old badassery. When the film ends, you'll instantly be in internal dialogue with yourself on whether or not you'd agree with Rorschach or Ozymandias. You'll contemplate what it means to see the world through the eyes of Dr. Manhattan. The film's portrayal of someone who transcends time and space is done masterfully. As I mentioned in my review of "Lucy", for the most part, our understanding of his abilities is portrayed from the perspective of other characters, and he still has links to humanity that are explored in the "Birth of Dr. Manhattan" sequence. The last wink at the audience with the journal is also a fantastic talking point. Was it all for nothing?

The overall "look" of the film is very gratifying for the most part. It's beautiful, grim and filled with contrasting colours. Every shot in this film is composed with so much focus that it's hard to not be drawn in. It isn't until we get moments of horrible CGI that we flinch a little. Snyder's over-reliance on computer-generated images tends to act as a crutch on his film. In cases where miniatures, practical effect and composites of real footage could have easily been used, you scratch your head when the camera pans from a real shot, to an obviously CG rooftop, to another real shot. Don't get me wrong, it looked great in the majority of the scenes, but the times that it stood out, it really stood out.

Hand-in-hand with the above, the slow-motion shots were a bit much at times. In my opinion, slow-motion has be used for purpose (ie the first "Matrix" and "Inception"), but once it's just for visual candy, it becomes a little exhausting and coupled with the crutching CG, it can really take you out of the scene (as it did for me in the opening sequence). But again, there were times where it was merited and for that I still give Snyder credit. 

The changes from the book are apparent for the most part. To me, there are two that stand out most - the first is how Rorschach deals with the murderer of the little girl. In the book, he handcuffs the killer to the furnace, hands him a saw and sets the house on fire. The filmmakers changed this due to possible association to the movie saw. Personally, I would've gone "the hell with that" and left it, but we don't know what powers were at play behind the scenes resulting in this change. The second is the big cataclysmic event at the end of the film. Without spoiling it too much, I enjoyed it a lot more than the one from the book. The original ending seemed to come out of nowhere and felt as though Alan Moore was sitting at his keyboard drunk and went "yeah, that'll do" before passing out on his bed. Although I prefer Snyder's ending, the fact that he left Bubastis in the film is confusing. Why would Ozymandias waste his time genetically engineering creatures if not for the original ending? It's just out of place and feels random without context and (again) the CGI looked awful. 

The music selection for this film was fantastic in the way in fit the story with the exception of a couple of songs. At times it made the film feel like a parody (of Apocalypse Now with the Vietnam sequence) or a scene from Smallville (Comedian' funeral) and although the scenes on their own are great, they stand out like a soar thumb in context of the rest of the film. One of them that stood out most was the awkward pairing of picture to sound during the sex scene - really irked me. Aside from those select pieces, great selection. This category is one that people still find themselves quarrelling over when it comes to this film.

At the end of the day, I loved this film and I'll give it a solid 9/10.

For a full list of changes between the Director's Cut and the Theatrical Cut click here.

Watchmen was a socially-relevant, very gritty graphic novel from the late 80s written by one of the most original comic book writers of the time (or any time), Alan Moore.

Many of Alan's books have been made into movies.  From Hell.  V for Vendetta.  The League of Extraordinary Gentlemen.  And he refuses to put his name on any of them because he thinks movies are pointless drivel.

So, for over 20 years, people have been trying to prove Alan wrong and find a way to put his "masterpiece," Watchmen, into film form.  And no one had the balls, or technology, to accomplish it.  

Until now.

First off, Zack Snyder has done the PERFECT translation of Watchmen into film.  There is no way it could have ever been done better.  Ever.  By anyone.  

However, that still doesn't mean the book translates to film well.  It doesn't.  At all. 

Zack is very aware of how much it is possible to forever ruin Watchmen by making it into a cheesy movie, so he sticks to the source material almost verbatim.  This makes for an interesting viewing experience, if you've read the book.  It's like the book is being read to you.

However, it's like the book is being read to you.

It doesn't have a movie flow.  It has a book flow.  The film struggles to emotionally connect you with any character, except for Rorschach, who is the highlight of the film.  PERFECT casting. And being so distant from the era of the cold war, even though we are seeing hints of it again, it's incredibly difficult to feel what the book made readers feel in the 80s when the cold war was so prevalent.

From the perspective of being faithful to the book, Zack should be commended and, in that respect, the film is perfect, even if they replaced the giant squid with nuclear explosions.  It's a 5 star film.

However, from a film-watcher's perspective, it was too long (and, yes, I realize it had to be), it was too dated (and, yes, I realize it had to be), it was too boring and it did not flow well at all, though I think it picked up in the last half hour.  

If you were a fan of the book, you HAVE to see it.  If you have no idea about the book, do not waste your 3 hours and $15.

Side note:  I was a huge comic book reader in the 1980s.  What made Watchmen important was that, at the time, in the era of Ronald Reagan and the Cold War, what was weird was that comic book writers would not tackle the subject of nuclear war.  It was almost like a silent rule that even though super heroes are supposed to save us from everything, we all know writing that a super hero could stop nuclear war is just dumb and unrealistic (even though the concept of super heroes themselves is dumb and unrealistic).  It was very strange.  Since no one could figure out a way to have a hero stop EVERY nuclear missile before hitting their targets, they just avoided the subject. 

So when Alan Moore decided to tackle the subject head-on, he did it in a very unique way, and probably the only way it would have made sense.  In Watchmen, the heroes manipulated mankind from destroying themselves.  THAT is the way they saved them.  They brought them together by making a common enemy from which they could unite.  The heroes didn't have to "stop all the bombs."  They simply had to manipulate the leaders from ever wanting to release the bombs.  

It was genius. 

Alan's disgust of the government, status quo, etc., and his story's descent into chaos are themes in many of Alan's stories.  V for Vendetta is another great example (and much better done film).  He is a master storyteller though, and superb character developer.  Rorschach, in particular, comes across to me as Alan himself, which is why I think the character appeals to the reader so much.  Uncompromising and blunt, like Alan himself.

I watched this after school one day without seeing the trailer; I had no expectations and this film ultimately over-delivered quite effectively. I'm writing this review in retrospect because I enjoyed it so much though much of my memory is blurred.

What I do remember is that the tone was very dark and haunting which was particularly ironic given the constant motif of the smiling yellow face-pin thing. I think that's what did it for me, I have an irrational penchant towards dark films. I also like confusing plots, or at least ones that reveal themselves slowly throughout the movie. Sometimes I'm just thick that day and can't see the ending, which means I'll probably enjoy the movie. Watchmen kept me guessing from the beginning though, with the Comedian scene and the blood splash as a tear on the yellow pin. That scene remains vivid in my memory today. The rest of the movie had no real issues in terms of acting, plot, and visuals. I was genuinely engrossed at every moment and felt bad for Owlman the whole time since he's like a parody of Batman. The ending was very appropriate and looking back, the film provided an interesting perspective on world peace. I can't say if my exaltation of the film was a product of circumstance and if I would have enjoyed it at a later age. However, at that point in time, it was a great film and I still view it as one of my favorites even today.

Zach Snyder's WATCHMEN movie is a pretty remarkable achievement; substantially faithful to the acclaimed comics series, while trimming and paring the story down to fit into a two and three quarter hour movie. The distinct visual style of the comic book is effectively substituted with a distinct and highly stylized cinematic style.

After a few viewings and after a few years, I don't find Rorschach's growling, hoarse delivery as off-putting as I did the first time I saw the movie. Perhaps it seems much more natural now in contrast to the Nolan/Bales Batman.  Laurie Jupiter doesn't seem quite as stiff a performance, either, as it did at first. But the use of Leonard Cohen's "Hallelujah" is still too "on the nose."  Great soundtrack, though.

All in all, quite an accomplished super hero noir combining heavy doses of both the visceral and the thoughtful.

This seems to be quite a polarizing movie, but as someone who'd never read the graphic novel, I must admit that I really loved this film. It wasn't perfect, but it was still a gripping ride.

The story is set in an alternate 1985, with the threat of nuclear annihilation imminent. Years ago, a group of superheroes - The Comedian, the Night Owl, the Silk Spectre, Ozymandias, Rorschach and Dr. Manhattan - were the protectors of America, winning the country the Vietnam War, eradicating criminal syndicates and making Richard Nixon the most popular President of all-time. But the Watchmen have long gone, shut down by the Government among civilian unrest. When the Comedian is murdered, it brings about a chain of events that lead the surviving Watchmen to regroup to fend off attacks to themselves and save human existence.

The film stars Malin Akerman, Billy Crudup, Matthew Goode, Carla Gugino, Jackie Earl Haley, Jeffrey Dean Morgan and Patrick Wilson - all of whom do a servicable job of bringing to life their deranged and possibly dangerous characters.

It's a creepy, dark, introspective film - certainly a far cry from the Saturday morning superhero range. But what it brings is a bleak and honest outlook on the human condition, bringing forward a fate where death and destruction are the only options. It also deals with human interactions, as vastly different people come to terms with each other.

And, to top it off, it does it with an eclectic and memorable soundtrack! (I do love a good soundtrack).

A solid 9/10 for me. Definitely Zack Snyder's best film.

Zack Snyder outdid himself on this and I salute him for this piece of comic book movie art. It's the perfect adaptation of an amazing graphic novel and you have too see it too believe it.

Normally the flow of Superhero movies is like - a protagonist who has some powers and wants to serve society, his archenemy, his love interest, innocent citizens & an entire city reduced to ashes during final combat so that citizens can live in peace. But Watchmen breaks all this standard cliches & comes up with something that is just par excellence. All are costumed vigilantes here no one is superhero (except Dr. Manhattan), Human beings are no innocent as Comedian says "Human's savage nature is itself the cause of their annihilation", an entire city is reduced to ashes but for something that is ultimately good & there is no specific villain - everyone is fucking right at their respective places. Hatsoff Alan Moore for creating such an awesome storyline & big pat on Zack Snyder's back for a visual style that is just unmatchable right from starting fight till end climax. Each and every fucking scene is a gem. Definitely Rorschach & Comedian's ideologies will be revolving in my head for some more days to come.

Watchmen Spoiler Free Review
Story: The basic plot of Watchmen was about a group of retired vigilantes (superheroes) who are now required to come out of retirement in order to face the crisis of possible all out nuclear war between the USA and the Soviets. Normally this would be a pretty standard plot about a team of heroes who must come back together however making it take place during the time of the cold war really put a new spin on that concept which was a huge plus for the story. The structure of the movie is that it shows a bit of present day then it shows some flashbacks, it then continues to proceed like that. So you end up seeing a couple minutes of present day then a couple minutes of flashbacks. 
Protagonist(s): The protagonists are a team of former heroes known as the Watchmen. The team consists of Rorschach- a masked detective, Ozymandias- a billionaire genius, Silk Spectre- a girl who knows how to fight, Dr. Manhattan- production of a nuclear physics experiment accident, and Nite Owl- a low budget Batman. Nite Owl is seen as the least interesting character in the beginning but is an important character as he is the only reasonable and down to Earth character while the rest contain flaws. Rorschach is extremely judgmental, Ozymandias is arrogant, Dr Manhattan lacks empathy, and Silk Spectre is a whore. The one who stands out is Rorschach as he is truly one of the greatest badasses in fiction and has lots going on with him psychologically which gives him the most layers. The actors play their parts well with the exception of Silk Spectre, however she was not terrible just not as good as the rest. 
Action- The action in this movie is amazing. The thing that makes the action great is not the creativity (although that was a plus) but the visuals. Visually this movie is amazing in just about all aspects. Some scenes are gruesome and could possibly get under the skin of some people. 
Villain- All good comic book movies need a villain. Because the villain is shrouded in mystery however I will not be talking much about him. I will say this that he was a good villain and does a very good job. 
Music- The original score has nothing that special about it however it uses many songs in general that help make the tone darker and more gritty. 
Other aspects-This movie has a ton of satire in it. It talks about society, about government, and of course about how countries interact with each other. It also contains many great quotes, which can be applied not only to everyday life but also to entire nations and society as a whole. 
Cons- For the most part this movie was very enjoyable. The only thing that bugged me was Silk Spectre. She was annoying however that was primarily because of the actor that portrayed her. I feel as though if a better actor was used the character could be carried out better. 
Conclusion: With a dark and gritty tone Watchmen delivers both story wise and visually. The only problem that it has is that it tries to cram the graphic novel into one movie which can sometimes make the movie feel a bit rushed. My recommendation is to watch the directors or the ultimate cut which help the movie flow better.

A film which does have its flaws - some of the changes to the story are unwelcome, while it will most likely alienate some viewers with no knowledge of the source material - this film nonetheless has some of the most beautiful visuals, one of the best stories and some of the best performances of many films seen, the most notable performance being by Jackie Earle Haley, who does a phenomenal turn in his role of Rorschach.

I'll start by telling you I saw Watchmen in the theaters before I read the graphic novel, and I only read the book recently while simultaneously watching the director's cut of the film on Blu-ray. I wanted to completely immerse myself in this world before logging my thoughts, and for two whole evenings I'd read, then watched, read, watched, and compared.

Watchmen is set in an alternate 1980?s, where Richard Nixon is starting his third term as the president of the United States of America. It's a gloomy piece of work that presents the darker sides of human nature in a way that's begrudgingly believable. Costume vigilantes have been outlawed, but some still operate either secretly for the government, or privately through their own sense of justice. There's also the looming terrible inevitability of a nuclear war between the US and the Soviet Union, so you probably won't be too surprised when I tell you Watchmen is light on laughs.

After viewing the movie again and reading the graphic novel, I can tell you the film is very faithful to the source material. Obviously, a book of this size isn't going to make it to the screen without some concessions, but I believe writers David Hayter and Alex Tse have made a lot of great choices in their screenplay. Some elements play out of step with the novel, but in a way that makes sense. Some main characters also receive slightly less development, but not so much that would effect your understanding of the plot. Other sub-story components, like the Tales of the Black Freighter only make it into the Ultimate Cut of the film released on Blu-ray. But that omission doesn't really effect the main plot, and would only be noticed by fans of book.

I have to say I really enjoyed the book, and the film. I loved the varied characters, and the sombre tone of both media formats. The book is obviously more detailed because it can be, and I did find this format does a better job of explaining how Dr Manhattan (the only 'superhero' in this story to have powers), views time and space. On the other hand, I found the end of the movie to work better than the novel.

The movie also strikes the right tone, and while grim I liked its depiction of human nature for good or bad. The characters in this story are black, white and every shade of gray in between. The society they live in has lost its way, and each hero fights to contain the madness. The ultimate solution to this crisis ends up being extreme, but oddly convincing as a way to move forward, while simultaneously exposing the childish nature of humanity, and restoring a sadly required belief in a vengeful higher power.

Movie Prep:

If you've read the book, then you'll likely be okay with the movie. The sections of the book it leaves out are not overly critical to the plot and understanding of the characters. However, if you haven't read the book, this movie may be a little hard to follow. If you're in the mood for a more adult and somber comic book story, then this is the movie to watch. The movie earns its R rating through its depiction of sexuality and often extremely graphic violence.

Best Format:

This is a beautifully shot film, and there are some moments that are truly spectacular to watch. If your local movie theater were screening this I suggest you catch that show. At home a HD viewing of the director's cut on a nice big TV is the way to go. Watching this on a smaller tablet or phone sized screen would be a mistake.

Best Element:

I absolutely loved the performance by Jackie Earle Haley as Rorschach. Brooding, violent and even a touch vulnerable, with a psychotic obsession for right and wrong. The unmasked scenes he has throughout the film are some of the most entertaining and powerful moments in the movie.

In a market where super hero movies are in overabundance, Watchmen gets made and really has something to say. It isn't a flashy popcorn flick of good guys and bad guys, it's a very complex tale with a lot of grey areas. Getting this made in the first place is already amazing but the fact it was made for wide release is great. For a potential chunk of the demographic of people who probably have never read the graphic novel and keeping it so faithful is quite bold. It's dark, brooding, intelligent, slow paced and doesn't even have anyone in costume for a large majority of it. It goes against most of the norms of comic books movies of today. With The Dark Knight Trilogy and Iron Man 3 being excluded because a) The Dark Knight trilogy is intelligent and b) Iron Man 3 because Shane Black hates the characters and couldn't wait to get Tony Stark out of that suit. But I digress, we're talking about a good film here.

It might be hypocritical to say it is a faithful adaptation of the graphic novel because I have not read it, I have however owned it for a long time but never read it because I thought it was only half of the story and a few other reasons. I got it along with a bunch of other stuff when I was quite young, I had no urge to read it just because... I didn't. After seeing the film I did go to the book and flick through a few choice pages and it did indeed look faithfully recreated, some of the shots that are in the book have been translated expertly to the big screen. I have heard the directors cut is the way to go but I will read the book first and then watch that and maybe the ultimate cut too. But first of all I just wanted to watch the film that everyone else saw in the movie theatre and have an unbiased opinion it. 

By itself though the film really does hold up. It has a fantastic, strong story played out with great characters by good actors that actually look like the characters from the book, with Jackie Earle Haley looking like a young Clint Eastwood in some parts. Even though I know who most of these actors are it does help to have smaller names in a film like this, so you can look past the actor and just see the character and even more so by looking at some of the casting for this in years past, Robin Williams, really? Not like I don't like Williams but it would indeed distract. 

While it is commendable that such a big Hollywood production that really does need to make a profit has smaller known actors, I do think that sometimes the acting was a bit off. Patrick Wilson is a very good actor, and one I love to see, as is Jeffrey Dean Morgan, especially Jackie Earle Haley who is the very definition of a character actor as even his small role in All the Kings Men he is unrecognisable and hey we even have Max Headroom in here but some of the lines delivered by Billy Crudup at some points were kind of flat and Malin Akerman's performance was just downright bad!

Everything technical about the film is absolutely remarkable, the lighting, the cinematography and with some exceptions the sound mixing and everything else! Zack Snyder really is a visionary director as he has crafted not only a great film but everything looks so beautiful and unique, the violence pops and the slowmo scenes actually work here and they only show for about 2 seconds each. Also, the script is rich in detail and being co-written by comic book fanatic, Solid Snake, er, I mean David Hayter, and it shows (and some other guy who wrote it)

While I think the film is great there are some problems with it, I think the film could use a bit more editing, some flashback scenes go on a bit too long and some of the dialogue is sometimes quite hard to hear either because of the way the actors portrayed the lines or because the sound mixing was a bit off. Also, I started to feel the pace of the film near the end. While it is deliberately slow on purpose to get everything on the big screen that it possibly can from the book and to not make it feel rushed but it starts to show near the end, it didn't bother me because I was enjoying the film so much but I did notice it. Given the time constraints of Hollywood movies, even with this clocking in at over the general movie length time of two hours, its amazing at what has been accomplished and that none of it feels rushed. The soundtrack did seem rather odd in this, while all the songs are pretty good, most of them seem to come out no where and make some scenes quite awkward. 

Considering how much I did like this for someone who didn't really know anything about it, I'm looking forward to watching the other cuts of this film and seeing how much my love will grow, or deteriorate because I'll start to notice stupid little things that no one cares about, but I really can't see that happening as this is a good translation, at least from what I have seen so far and what others tell me but there was no squid! It's a great super hero film but its much more than that, its a dark crime saga more than anything else. I watched this film at just the right time and it really made me happy and most of all just gave me faith in the genre. It has deep, well written characters, a great story, fantastic visuals and for the most part is acted well, it's great to see something go against the easy cash grab big name actors and conventional storytelling to draw in audiences, it's deeply rewarding and thrilling viewing.

Wirh Zack Snyder taking on the superhero genre as it's surface appeal, Watchmen sounded like a film with great potential. 

I struggled to be able to pinpoint the actual time that the story took place in because Watchmen the plot structure is confusing. It keeps on going back and fourth between flashbacks and present day, so much that I failed to understand  when present day actually is. I was uncertain if the Cold War theme was a flashback or if it was the actual time setting of the film. Watchmen struggles to actual establish when it is happening, and since there are so many characters and so many flashbacks happening, it is difficult to be certain. Zack Snyder's ambition for staying true to all the characters and storylines in the Watchmen source material is grand, but there is so much for him to capture that he can't get everything right. I just wish I knew when the story was happening, because the structure of the narrative is rather convoluted and the sensibility of the film is uncertain. I really don't know when things are happening and if they are part of a single narrative or a series of them, and it left me puzzled and asking a lot of questions which didn't get answered by Zack Snyder. And if it is all set in the 1980's, I couldn't really find anything to consistently reinforce that because the production design of everything simply felt modern thanks to such high quality camera work. Things feel very modern in Watchmen, and that reinforces a confusion as to when things are meant to be occurring. Maybe it's an example of having to read something before watching it, but either way the complex plot structure was a little overwhelming.
And at the same time, Watchmen moves at a very slow pace for a period of 155 minutes. I know that one of the themes of it being a Neo- noir superhero film means that it is going to move at a slow pace, and the fact that it is a character oriented superhero film with many characters means that it is going to substitute action for dialogue, but this proves to be both Watchmen's finest aspect and it's downfall. In the negative way of speaking, having to watch a 155 minute superhero film which is short on action means that it will be slow. And that is the case. While I appreciated the characters, I also found that since the quality of the action scenes was excellent, the quantity by comparison was dissaponting. The few action scenes that there were in Watchmen were incredibly well done thanks to an ideal mix between action choreography and visual effects. If there was only a larger quantity of them then Watchmen would be more sensible, but since they are placed so sporadically over the course of the 155 minute running time, it reinforces the slow pace of the film. 
And lastly, the ending of the story was so conflicting to me that I didn't know how to feel. Usually this is a good feeling, but just the fact that in a matter of very little time the fate of Rorschach was suddenly turned around was so controversial to me, especially since he was my favourite character. I, like the characters in the film, was very conflicted by how the story ended. And the fact that the film spend so long building to it only to give out an ending which was somewhat confusing, complex and hard for me to face left me with mixed feelings. It seems as if it's hard to fully understand the motivations behind the characters in the end without reading the source material, and since after that it was all over, I really just did not know how to feel.
The impatient are not the right viewers for Watchmen, but fans of innovative filmmaking are because it is a more thoughtful and ambitious effort on behalf of director Zack Snyder. The style of the film is very interesting, because it captures both the large scale feel of a true superhero film and the small scale darkness that comes with being a Neo-noir. Watchmen serves as an innovative blend of the genres because it's colour is consistently dark and gritty to fit into the Neo- noir theme, and yet it is also electric at times to capture the superhero theme. It's central colour is a dark but electric blue which serves as a symbol of the mix of both genres, and it gives Watchmen memorable colour. 
And also, the cinematography follows the same style. Finding an interesting balance between close up and intensely focused shots and wide scaled big shots, Watchmen simultaneously captures the scale of a high profile superhero film and a character focused Neo-noir which gives it an interesting atmosphere. The cinematography captures the magnificent visual elements of Watchmen as well such as it's creative costumes, it's grand production design and the magnificent quality of the visual effects. And it is all edited well against the backdrop of a strong soundtrack which is commonly mood setting and atmospheric. So Watchmen is a great visual experience with many technical delights.
And although the storytelling is far from perfect, the script in Watchmen consistently contains strong dialogue for the actors to work with and gives them very strong characters.
Jackie Earle Hailey is incredibly badass in Watchmen. For much of the film he has to act behind a mask, doing the same kind of thing that Christian Bale did in his portrayal of Batman. And he manages to do it well because he puts a lot of emotion into his voice even though he keeps it in the same deep and angry voice all the time. He creates several different pitches of intensity for the character. When his mask is off, we see the true darkness of him. When he has his mask on he builds his character on the basis of his deep voice and his physical movements whereas when he takes the mask off he has an intense stare to add to it. Jackie Earle Haley keeps his emotions in the role of Rorschach within the appropriate limits, and he makes the character unforgettable with awesome fierce dedication to the part which projects an intimidating demeanour and a lot of though. Jackie Earle Haley gives an immaculate performance in Watchmen and it is the best performance of the film which reinforces the second coming of his acting career as a legendary move. 
Malin Akerman packs a powerful role in Watchmen. With the film capitalising on both her sex appeal and her rough edged line delivery, Watchmen manages to capture the gritty material of her acting skills. She packs a serious punch as a hero due to her fierce strength, and her involvement in the material. Her chemistry with the many other actors is fine and she creates a certain sense of mystery which is beneficial to the audience and has them curious about her and finding her to be a compelling figure. Malin Akerman makes a powerful effort in Watchmen and it seriously pays off.
Billy Crudup's role is mostly under the guise of visual effects, the importance in his role mainly comes from his voice articulation. He constantly maintains the same tone of voice, but you can tell a lot of the emotions from within him which he projects subtly that he has feelings and simply keeps them in tact so that they don't result in a negative effect on the universe. He delivers his lines as if he has the genuine wisdom and genius of the character, and it makes him fitting for the role very well. Billy Crudup maintains the ideal scientific intelligence for the character by making it seem natural, and he makes a memorable presence in Watchmen.
Jeffrey Dean Morgan is perfect for the role of The Comedian. In a realistic manner, he captures the man as a hero who has become truly angry at everything he is fighting and turned merciless in his treatment of those who oppose him. While the sight is brutal, it is easily compelling because as far as superheroes go I rarely find them gritty enough. The Comedian doesn't joke around, he exacts swift and harsh vengeance where it is die which makes him a great character, and Jeffrey Dean Morgan captures the rough and fierce edge for the character without problem. It is an impressive performance and it shows some of his finest acting skills, so Jeffrey Dean Morgan is a spot on casting decision in Watchmen.
Patrick Wilson and Matthew Goode gives decent supporting performances as well.

So although Watchmen is burdened by a convoluted plot structure, a slow pace and extensive length, the visual style of the film and the acting manage to overshadow it and make it an invigorating experience as well as one of Zack Snyder's more thoughtful projects.

Zack Snyder apparently has a reputation for not being a particularly smart director, and Watchmen is a phenomenally smart novel, so it may not seem like the best fit. And it may not be the best fit. But Snyder seems to have at least had the sense (and honestly I don't know enough about his work to think that I'm treating him fairly here) to let the work speak for itself. The directors cut, which I watched, his the most faithful adaptation I've ever seen, a nearly scene for scene, line for line representation of the graphic novel, even sharing the majority of the same composition, set design, color schemes, etc. So, insofar as watchmen itself is artful and character rich and intelligent, so is the movie. There isn't much additional artistry - the musical cues especially are often unsubtle, a bit too on the nose. And surely another director could have brought a more original vision that would take more advantage of the unique possibilities of film.

The one major change that Snyder and his team did make was, in my opinion, a very intelligent one. They removed the least relevant and stylistically consistent subplot and replaced it with a seamless and intuitive move relating to some of the main characters. It adds another layer of drama and tragedy and actually brings greater resolution to the relevant character arcs, without sacrificing anything that I felt to be terribly important.

The one major place I responded differently to the film than to the novel was the tenement fire rescue. It's interesting that this scene serves the same function for the viewer as it does for the characters, which I always feel is a really good sign. The unambiguous moral good of the situation gives us permission to just revel in the loud rock music, the fire, and the bad ass comic hero action. It is a touchstone for the simple moral dualism and noble derring-do that are deconstructed by the complexities of real life throughout the rest of the novel/film.

Having never read the comic book, I was surprised by what I took from Watchmen. I expected its dark and paranoid atmosphere, fueled by the historical context of the Cold War almost definitely breaking out into nuclear missile fire, to be what I liked the most. Not the case. What struck me the most were the superheroes and supervillains of no superhuman powers (minus Dr. Manhattan, a reborn man who can perceive and manipulate time and space in badass ways) and distinctly different agendas and views on the human race. I could make a chart out of these agendas. Night Owl and Silk Spectre II (whose mother, the first Silk Spectre, was of the original Minutemen during the 1940s) prefer small-scale and short-term victories, wanting to save one life without having to risk another's life. They let the country handle appropriate punishments. Rorschach, who wears an inkblot mask, also prefers small-scale and short-term victories, but has little forgiveness for those who do moral wrong. When given the opportunity, he takes matters in his own hands. The Comedian, an original Minuteman and later Watchman whose opening sequence death is one of the film's main mysteries, has little forgiveness for those who do relative wrong. That is, if you are not on board with the Comedian, he will not hold back any punches (or bullets). Ozymandias prefers long-term victories, with a love for the human race undermined by less humane and seemingly farfetched ambitions. And the aforementioned Dr. Manhattan loses all faith and compassion for humanity, letting them choose their fate. Watchmen is similar to supergroups like Justice League and Avengers, where these superheroes are mostly human and easily distinguishable. Watchmen goes one step further in that there is no common cause between characters.

I am even more surprised that I managed to follow character development, given the thickness of the storyline. In the film's first half-hour, someone kills off a character as part of a possible attempt to eliminate the Watchmen, the history of the Watchmen is outlined through a comic-stylish opening credits sequence to the tune of Bob Dylan's "The Times They Are A-Changin'", each main character is introduced, and so is the fear of the U.S. or the Soviet Union sending out nukes at any minute. With a running time of nearly three hours, I was nevertheless afraid that the film could not resolve all of the proposed conflicts. Yet it was done. Thank you, comic creator Alan Moore... albeit with a confusing narrative that involves non-chronological flashbacks. Thank you, director Zack Snyder. What helps less is a lack of playfulness in the movie. It's not that I was bored without humour for too long, but even when characters were out of the dark, they still seemed afraid to smile. I have never been more interested in reading a comic book than now. If I read the book before the movie, I may have disappointed myself. Thankfully, I can say that the strongest elements of the story of Watchmen far outweigh the scattered, grave direction of the film adaptation.

A movie that fails to add anything meaningful to the Watchmen universe. Despite some genuinely great moments, there's just as many poorly executed ones, and most of the movie is surprisingly flat. A lot of stiff acting doesn't help much either.

Where a great movie can bring cinematic life into its source material, this movie feels like a slave to the graphic novel, including scenes only because it happened in the book, not because they make sense on screen. The graphic novel is easily one of the greatest of all time. But this story was intended to be a graphic novel, and it's story works because of the unique art style and perspective a graphic novel can give us. It's strange to say, but the movie actually tries too hard to be faithful to the source material, including every subplot and character interaction but not giving them enough time to become meaningful. Despite a nearly 3 hour run-time, the movie feels rushed.

One other problem I had was the violence level. It simply distracts from the story. While the novel was obviously brutal at times, that was never the focus. Fight scenes that only last a few frames in the book are expanded into long, choreographed action scenes whose only purpose is to viscerally entertain us. Zack Snyder just can't seem to help himself.

Watchmen certainly is not like most superhero movies. While it begins and ends with some fantastic action, most of its center is based around a compelling, dramatic story that poses some unexpectedly deep questions to the viewer. The cast do a solid job in the acting department, and action (or at least what little there is) looks smooth and brutal. Thankfully, the story moves at a brisk enough pace that it doesn't feel as long as it is, and side stories never feel forced - they remain both interesting and relevant to the tale the movie is trying to tell. Regardless of the mixed critical response, I had a great time with this - it's like a superhero movie for adults.

Despite the foolishness of the general public, Watchmen is a deeply political and moral  beauty of a movie. Fraught with deep symbolism, each re-watch will reveal more and more of the brilliance that makes this movie one of the best. Featuring a relatively unknown cast that steps perfectly into the role of unknown superheroes, this movie brings together excellent and creative character development, surprisingly exciting and believable powers, as well as an intricate and well planned plot to create one of the great hidden masterpieces. Watch closely folks, nothing is as it seems in this movie. Take nothing for granted and never underestimate its ability to wow the viewer, even after multiple showings. The soundtrack fits the movie to a tee and makes for great listening no matter what your thoughts on the movie were.

From the humble beginnings as a 1980s comic book, Watchmen has turned the movie going experience into a life of its own. It's extraordinary visuals and cohesive character development has turned this movie into a new kind of cinema. From director Zach Snyder, this film has set the bar for all comic book movie lovers.
Watchmen's visual effects have shaped the way for what comic book movies need to be. Zach Snyder has filled every scene with vibrant colors and settings that made fans fall in love with the book thirty years ago. Each character's costume stays true to the original drawings of the famous Watchmen characters. Dr. Manhattan, a surprisingly electric blue man, stands out on the screen with his ominous presences but also with excellent full body shots of his glowing form. It is also hard to ignore the constantly changing ink blot on Rorschach's mask as he expresses various emotions from scene to scene. The attention to detail of each character's outfit in the film should have the audience glued to the screen at all times. 
Even the settings of an altered universe in New York City have costumes of their own. The streets show the decay of a corrupted city with prostitutes and graffiti posters of Richard Nixon across every alley way. Every background has a specific kind of setting that involves what is occurring in each scene. An example of this is when Dr. Manhattan and the Silk Spectre have a conversation on the red planet of Mars while afloat on a shimmering glass castle. The scene is set up where the castle is as beautiful and fragile as the relationship of the two heroes.
The character development of the ensemble cast has been the best seen in cinema. Each character has the perfect amount of face time to explain their backstories. Whenever a backstory is told it is smoothly set into the plot with no confusions or awkward breaks. One of my favorite scenes is when the heroes attend a funeral of one of their own, The Comedian. Each character has a flashback on how they individually were affected by his actions during their night of vigilante heroisms. Night Owl has a flashback where he and The Comedian are stopping a protest against the Watchmen. During the scene Night Owl asks, "What happened to the American Dream?" and The Comedian responds, "It came true! You're looking at it." The Comedian states the true savagery of civilization and Night Owl realizes that humanity may not be worth saving after all. Again, without having an awkward self-monologue within the scene, Night Owl's character is developed smoothly throughout the plot, as with the other heroes.
In another scene, Dr. Manhattan watches The Comedian shoot a pregnant woman in cold blood showing how malicious The Comedian can be. It also shows how Dr. Manhattan is slowly losing his connection with human life. The scenes have fluidity throughout the movie but also making sure that everything is explained to the point where the audience can follow along.
Watchmen is a visual masterpiece thanks to its costume and set design but also its visual parallels that it incorporates within the plot. The heroes are developed in a way where there is no need for drawn out dialogue, but also elaborates on each hero and their effect on the story. Zach Snyder has taken a critically acclaimed book and turned it into a character driven eye popping experience.

Six years since its release, "Watchmen" has slowly gained the respect it truly deserves: not just as an extremely faithful adaptation of Alan Moore's graphic novel but, more importantly, as a masterful piece of filmmaking that stands triumphant on its own. The damaged heroes are treated with genuine complexity, the meaning is deeply provoking, and the engrossing drama is built on terrifying realism.
Like Snyder's other films, this one succeeds more in its visual ascetics than in its plotting. At least there's a nice background soundtrack to listen to when characters fall into their monologues.

Watchmen is set in an alternate 1985 America in which costumed superheroes are part of the fabric of everyday society, and the Doomsday Clock which charts the USA's tension with the Soviet Union moves closer to midnight. When one of his former colleagues is murdered the masked vigilante Rorschach sets out to uncover a plot to kill all past and present superheroes. As he reconnects with his former crime fighting legion a disbanded group of retired superheroes  only one of whom has true powers Rorschach glimpses a wide ranging and disturbing conspiracy with links to their shared past and catastrophic consequences for the future. Their mission is to watch over humanity. It feels like this movie has no pulse, no energy, and you feel as if the movie is too long (which it is 2hr and 43mins damn!) when they play music in different scenes its horrible particularly the porn scene I don't know what that was about. Jackie Earle Haley was the stand out performer as Rorschach he kept my attention throughout the whole movie playing a psychopathic and paranoid role with such ease, but I feel like this movie should have been way better then it actualy was it showed potential.

I love this movie and own it.  It's the most intelligent and twisted comic book adaptation I've seen besides Sin City.  If you are looking for X-Men, the Avengers or Fantastic 4 this isn't your movie- this movie is very dark.  The line between good guys and bad guys is blurred and it's just so human despite the abilities that the heroes have.   While usually the vigilante ensemble is made to appear more good conquers evil this one uses evil to cause a greater good.  Really fascinating and thought provoking when you see the vulnerability of the characters, their views of humankind, as well as their bloody violent side in action conflicting within themselves what "greater good" means. I have not read the comic so I'm going off the film alone and that's where some negative ratings may come from- from what I understand some of the slow motion scenes in action were directly staged from a scene in the book.  The closest mainstream character who would fit this is Batman, or the Dark Knight however Watchmen goes all out gritty with the good and the gore.

When I first saw Watchmen in the theater, I did not like it. It seemed too long and loosely connected. A few years later, I rewatched the director's cut and now I see why it's so great. The style is unique, the action isn't too over-the-top (for a comic book movie) and the story (the most important thing in this case) is actually very good. It's extremely rare nowadays to find a comic book movie with a well-written script. This film is nothing like today's Marvel movies. It's got class, and a dark sense of style. The only thing wrong with it is the makeup on the actor that plays Richard Nixon, and the actor himself. He looks and sounds like a comedically exaggerated version of Nixon, which does not match the tone of the movie. The three hour length did feel a little excessive at times, but maybe it was the very fact that it was so long made the emotional ending punch harder. Great performances from everyone as well, especially from Billy Crudup as Dr. Manhattan and Jackie Earle Haley as Rorschach.
