Watchmen is one of the most severely underrated films I've seen and is one of my top 10 favourite films ever. Adapting Alan Moore's revered cult graphic novel wouldn't have been an easy task considering the seeming 'unfilmable' nature of the story. However, Zack Snyder amazingly delivered with it. The film is longer than most superhero films (though it's the same length as The Dark Knight Rises) but that's acceptable because of the lengthy story and each of the central characters are fully realised and the actors all fit their roles. Jackie Earle Haley is the standout as Rorschach with his menacing growl and subtle tenderness underneath the threatening persona. However, the other actors all do phenomenal work like Billy Crudup as the mystical Dr Manhattan and Matthew Goode as Ozymandias. The visuals compliment the tone greatly and feel like the comic book has come to life fully on the big screen. As this was the first big budget superhero film to be given an 18 rating, there is tonnes of violence and gritty subject matter which makes it stand out from most comic book films and feels like something innovative for our time. Even The Dark Knight feels tame by comparison. You may either love or hate this film but you sure can't deny that it's ambitious and definitely brings something new to the world of costumed heroes.
Hard to swallow, poorly adaptation of a great graphic novel.

the film is excitingly brutal. it gets your heart pumping and you start to feel an exhilarating feel of violence overcome your senses. this is an action movie. its an action movie that's smart, powerful, and epic in every sense of the word. its epic in story, style, scope, and length. its strong with its performances and character studies, its wise in its plot and world it creates, its beautiful for its truth on its commentary on society and politics. it says everything about how society has taken over the world we live in through government power, corporate power, and vigilantism. its just an all around great film based on possibly the greatest comic book of all time.
Two thums up! With a lot of reflections, good action, realistic superheroes and great history, is one of the best superheroes movies ever made!

Say what you will about the always controversial transition from paper to celluloid, but this is a masterful piece of visual storytelling. Snyder is a brilliant composer of images and less a proprietor of character work, and that fact is generally what deters me from his work, his stunningly strong re-adaptation of DAWN OF THE DEAD notwithstanding. However, WATCHMEN has the added benefit of being based on one of the great literary works of all time, as well as an astounding cultural study and a study of human nature, using superheroes as the catalyst for that.

The graphic novel, Watchmen by Alan Moore is one of my favorite books and one of the best graphic novels ever written, if not the best. It is a groundbreaking piece of literature gold that deserves to be worshiped. Yes, I just recently read the book and I missed this in theaters. But I know now how all those poor soles walking into the theater one night with their personal Watchmen copy in hand just awaiting this monumental adaptation to flash before their eyes feel. It does not feel very good.
I'm going to level with you, Watchmen wasn't awful. It was actually a pretty decently filmed movie. That meaning it looked great. Zack Snyder really has a talent for visual thrills because this looked beautiful. It had that Dark Knight look to it, but it had that polished and gleaming flare to it also. Snyder has style, and if only he can get a good script to go with it and he could be legendary.
Watchmen also had something else that blew me away. It has the best opening titles I have ever seen. They play out after the first scene and they aren't your normal opening credits just showing the people behind it. They do show that, but behind a series of slow-mo scenes where it's telling you all about the world your about to delve into. It shows the whole back story with the song The Times They Are A-Changin'  playing. That is the one time in this movie that I will say the song actually fits the scene, but it did.
Now time to talk about all of the faults. I thought the music choices were bad. The choices for the soundtrack were very interesting choices. The songs they chose for each scene did not fit well with what was happening on screen and as a result, it took away from the impact. This was a problem, but it wasn't the biggest problem I had with this movie. The biggest problem I had was the excessive and graphic gore throughout. It's this CG blood that flies everywhere when people are shot or hurt and it constantly comes splattering everywhere like it's Gears of War. It's comedic at certain moments and it really detracts from the scene. It doesn't even look good and that really bothered me.
In the end, Watchmen has the same problem that another adaptation had, The Great Gatsby. It is maybe a bit too faithful to the source material. I watch this movie knowing exactly whats going to happen, exactly what I will see, and even exactly what people say.They literally have line by line quotes straight from the book said in this movie, and some of the story board was taken directly from the graphic novel comic strip boxes. There's no new spin on it and it ends up just feeling like you copied off another person's school project and didn't put any real effort to call it your own.
Watchmen may be ambitious, but it sure isn't the best adaptation that the classic book could have had. That's another of the biggest problem with this movie, it has so much potential, but is squandered by the soundtrack, excessive gore, and a vision a bit too close to the source material. I really feel pity for those poor people at that midnight showing in 2009.

Snyder has done the impossible. Before Watchmen, his works were relatively empty, but Watchmen? Watchmen has depth, meaning and weight. It's not just a crazy superhero movie, it's a visual masterpiece, fearlessly acted, meaningful to the nature of storytelling and modern moviemaking. You could teach a class on this film. Watchmen is, to me, a f**king masterpiece.

While I strongly believe that creative liberties allow stories to be told across any medium,  a movie version of the Watchmen requires greater talent than Zack Snyder. While the script and actors are great, the distracting direction style essentially breaks the movie. The entire point behind the story is that heroes can only function on a small scale; anything larger than "cops and robbers" becomes morally grey with no easy solution or clear moral line. Each of our "heroes" are horribly flawed (we have an overweight shlub, a superficial vanity queen, a cold/distant freak, a psychotic serial killer, a self-righteous dystopian, and essentially a Nazi), yet Snyder takes every possible opportunity to elevate these characters to "bad-ass superhero" status. Much like his work on 300, Snyder manages to celebrate monstrous humans with action sequences of epic proportions and cinematography that makes them look godlike. The movie makes no attempt to hide it's glaring contradictions (celebrating the very issues the script is condemning), with Snyder even admitting that most of the creative decisions were made based on what would be the coolest. While the visuals are impressive, they betray the script and make the movie about as interesting or watchable as Kick-Ass.

To give you an idea of just how terrible this film is, it has earned the status of adjective among my family and friends to describe something truly awful.  For example, if you see a poor, obviously colour blind girl walking down the street in horrid shoes I might say this to one of my friends walking next to me, "Hey Terra, did you see that girl's shoes?  The were like Watchmen bad!"  What's so awful about it?  Where do I begin?  For starters the film is beyond confusing (and I consider myself a pretty sharp, engaged viewer).  The film is also way too long, and the fact that the viewer is left confused for the entire length of the film makes this length seem almost unbearable.  In addition to the previously stated reasons, I will add these:  horrible acting, terrible effects, and the worst sin of all, very bad story telling.  I'm not sure why the film makers thought it would be a good idea to make a film based solely on one confusing flashback and backstory after another but if I ever got the chance to tell them otherwise, I would with no qualms whatsoever.  I've heard others say this was an amazing film, and perhaps it was...for fanboys, but not for the general, uninitiated viewer.

[a unique superhero movie]
Watchmen (2009)
IMDB- 7.6
RottenTomatoes- 64%
RJG Ratings- 90

Rorschach,a vigilante ,starts an investigation after the death of a fellow vigilante.

Starring- Malin Akerman,Billy Crudup,Matthew Goode,Jackie Earle,Jeffrey Dean,Patrick Wilson
Director- Zack Snyder

The cast werent too well known actors back in 2009.But yet they give a good performance.Jackie Earle as Rorschach was my favorite.Patrick Wilson (Nite Owl2)& Jeffrey (Comedian) were great too.The best thing about Watchmen is that its a tale of 6 heroes ,and all of them have got a considerable amount of screentime and importance.This is mostly due to the excellent adaptation and good casting.

The story for Watchmen is a direct adaptation of Alan Moore's graphic novel.Watchmen has been considered for years as one of the greatest comic/graphic novel.It was widely considered to unfilmable till Snyder's attempt.The main issue here is the powerful story structure of the comic ,which is hard to limit in the time scope of a standard movie length.Plus the symbolism in the comic was a hard to follow.
Yet even with such challenges ,the movie is one heck of an adaptation.The story is just as dark as the comics and just as intense.It paints a picture of the bleary world the story of Watchmen is set in (alternative 1980's).Its a complex story but its well adapted.

In my opinion ,Watchmen is Zack Snyder's Best Work as of (May 2013).His level of commitment and faithful nature to the original comics is noteworthy.He does his best to mold the movie into the likes of the "unfilmable comic".The end result might not stand upto the comic book ,but we are talking about one of the greatest comic books of all time.
As a movie ,Watchmen is an extremely unique take on superheroes.Its a multiple genre movie ,and its pacing is even.It doesnt rush off but instead takes its time to build up the various plotlines of each character.Its not a normal superhero movie where you expect huge action sequences to pop up every now and then.On the surface its a detective movie ,but as i previously said its a multi layered movie.

The visual effects have been used moderately.Like Zack's previous attempt ,300 ,Watchmen's beauty is tripled with his choice of visual effects.Although Zack has done his best to make Watchmen a movie for all ,most casual viewers wont be satisfied.

Overall ,Watchmen isnt a popcorn flick.Its more of a study on the minds of vigilantes and 'cause and effect' of various actions.

Acting- 4/5
Story- 4.5/5
Direction- 4.5/5
Action- 4.5/5
Drama- 5/5
Suspense- 4/5

I loved the beginning of this and the images we saw during the credits, but after that I thought it went downhill.  I didn't like the arrangement of the current story and the backstories.  The music choices were all really, really weird and seemed out of place, and the slow-mo was used incredibly too much.  Parts were laughable when they shouldn't have been.  I thought it was overly preachy and way too long, and after a while I just didn't care about what was happening.  There were only two characters I was even interested in, and they were the only two who seemed to have any common sense at the end of the film.  The amount of blood in this movie rivaled a Quentin Tarantino film, not that it bothered me in particular, but I found this to be one of the heavier R rated movies I've seen in a while, and I was kind of surprised it didn't manage to get an NC-17 rating, despite how high profile it is.

On the good side, I thought the visual effects were stunning; it was a beautiful looking movie.  Nite Owl II was adorable and Rorshach's badassery never ceased to make me smile.  Dr. Manhattan's backstory was set-up perfectly and was the only moment in the film where I was really concerned and touched.  His narration over his story worked very well, and really made that sequence the best in the film for me.  Other than that, I was pretty annoyed by this movie; I really tried to like it, because it looked like it was going to be amazing and I've heard really good things from people whose opinions I usually trust, but it just wasn't for me.

Honestly, this isn't a GREAT movie. It is very boring at times, and it was kind of tough for me to sit through the whole thing. However, the film was entertaining to me at least, and I did overall enjoy it. Was it the best Superhero movie? Absolutely not. But was it a good Superhero movie? Absolutely. Also, this is kind of a "one-watch" movie for me. I don't think I would ever wanna sit through this enire thing again. There wasn't as much action as expected, and I think I did get my hopes up a little too high, however. But it was a good movie nonetheless.

Having cut his teeth on the fun zombie flick 'Dawn of the Dead' (2004) and ludicrously successful '300' (2007), Zack Snyder provides his best work to date with this clever, engaging and ultimately underrated comic book adaptation. 

Although key plot points are rather predictable, 'Watchmen' is nonetheless a fun piece of crime noir, set in an alternative 1985 world that's littered with intriguing characters. The performances are abundantly solid throughout, though Jackie Earle Haley as Rorschch and Billy Crudup as Dr. Manhattan, who has one of the most beautifully composed narrations in recent memory, steal the show. 

So much to take in and enjoy, 'Watchmen' is a pleasant surprise.

Watchmen is a problematic adaptation of Alan Moore's graphic novel making several attempts at being artistic with Snyder's signature stylistic visuals, noteworthy dialogue, and a convoluted execution that finds an imbalance between mystery, romance, and drama. Still, Watchmen's story is complex and thematically deep and should appeal to most movie-goers.

Even though it's based on a graphic novel, it's a great re-imagining of the superhero genre, though the character development falls slightly short once the sex comes in, and the story turns ridiculous once the third act begins.
Though much darker than most of its kind, it's a solid entry into the superhero franchise with some great characterization, good looking visuals, and entertaining action.

The mid-eighties were an exciting period of revitalization for the comic industry, particular for DC Comics, the publisher of titles involving such well known characters as Batman and Superman. The modern approach to Batman received a substantial part of its power in Frank Miller's, Batman : The Dark Knight Returns. In Crisis on Infinite Earths, the mainstream DC Universe with its array of parallel alternative universes was collapsed into one cosmos and many of the characters and their backgrounds were, to a greater or lesser degree, revised. The accumulated debris of decades of story writing was swept aside to make way for a more rational, leaner setting. 

Nowhere was this revisionism more radical than with the last son of Krypton. Superman is the idealization of the masculine West, matching as he does the power of a classical god like Apollo with the intense morality of the West's judaeo-christian heritage. Kal-el was depowered by several orders of magnitude, which greatly benefited story writing. It is interesting to note that some of the last stories written about Superman before the Crisis was a series by Alan Moore; an imaginary tale about the last days of the Silver Age Superman in which some long term enemies switch from being fairly ineffectual jokers to psychopaths on a murderous rampage, leading to Superman sacrificing all his powers and identity to save his friends and the woman he loves.

Alan Moore and Dave Gibbon's Watchmen remains as the most extraordinary example of this wonderful period in comics, or as we less embarrassingly refer to them, graphic novels. The most exciting idea from a superhero fan's perspective was taking the idea of the costumed hero and speculating on what might actually happen if masked vigilantism became real.

Watchmen rightly became a best seller. Its complex, reflexive storyline centres on the Cold War fear of a global nuclear war between the US and the Soviet Union. Taking in a lot of the history of the twentieth century, it charts the rise and fall of the costumed hero as the characters accelerate towards Armageddon. The climax is wish fulfilment for all of us who felt trapped in those times in a world with no seeming escape from atomic inferno. The Watchmen's heroes are not the straightforward types normally depicted in comics; they all have "issues" as we like to say now and nowhere is this more clear than the extraordinary psychological jump that would be required to don a costume and physically embattle society's worst elements.

Given its revolutionary scope and grown up themes in some ways it seemed inescapably excitingly enough to justify a full cinematic translation. But as the creator Alan Moore decreed, its sheer richness, density of narrative and bubbling list of characters could also make it seem "unfilmable". It has taken the best part of a quarter century for it finally to come to the screen.

As a long term Watchmen fan I became ensnared in the viral marketing campaign leading up to the release. Fascinated with the transformation into a cinematic production, I eagerly kept up to date with its octopusine internet presence almost to the point of becoming fatigued by its relentless outreaching. After over twenty years, could I really be losing interest as the release date finally approached?

Now that I've seen it I'm happy to relate that it is as near a perfect depiction of the comic book on the screen, more or less, that could ever be achieved. Zack Snyder has triumphed in bringing the world of Watchmen to life in a shocking visual and almost visceral experience.

The film effectively starts with the murder of the Comedian in a brutally powerful fight scene. We are instantly aware that though these characters might not be super-beings but are still astonishingly strong. The consistency of the production creates an immersive feel of another world, similar to ours but different. The brutality of the fight does not pull any punches and the audience cannot help but be drawn in. 

The first part of the film is a wonderful character exposition using the device, again following the comic book, of the Comedian's funeral. This is where the cutting back and forth between different periods is used most effectively. By necessity these are a selective short-hand for the equivalent sections in the novel but nevertheless clever choices have been made and this section is perhaps the most effective in the film.

Soon the plot starts to take over again and in some interesting divergences from the book we are shown additional edgings to the characters and their relationships not revealed before. Adrian Veidt seems to be the most different from the book; Rorschach the most accurate. Veidt's depiction interested me greatly. Here he is portrayed as a hubristic Euro-American with his softened Germanic accent and European fashions. I was reminded of a younger version of the characters the great Richard Lynch used to play in the eighties.

The film moves forward through Nite Owl, the most likeable of the Watchmen. His engaging portrayal allows the viewer into the plot. The changed ending is clever. It is a much more logical and efficient conclusion than the book's, albeit less colourful. I have always thought Watchmen's conclusion was more about wishing away the Cold War than providing a clear way out of World War III but still take the view that with the world a hair-trigger away from annihilation any extraordinary occurrence, whether it be the giant squid monster of the comic or the ending shown here, would still be a catalyst for an all out nuclear attack. 

The film is most successful when authentically showing important parts of the Watchmen story properly and allowing them the time needed. Rorschach's jail time is a case in point. At other, seemingly equally crucial, points the narrative is rushed so much I am not clear that anyone not familiar with Watchmen would really follow what is going on. How do Nite Owl and Rorschach so quickly work out that the whole scheme links back to Ozymandias? It is not clear how the Comedian uncovered Veidt's plot before his killing. The tenement fire rescue scene is forcibly truncated. Nite Owl's hacking of Veidt's computer (which must be a Mac - by the way apparently when looking through his computer's files, one of the folders is entitled "boys", another hint about Veidt's obscured sexuality) is treated very quickly. I have never been entirely satisfied with how easily Nite Owl and Rorschach work everything out, but this is symptomatic of the book as well as the film. The world's smartest man has an important password that is the title of a book near his desk or which happens to be the real name of his superhero identity? It seems unlikely.

Veidt's motivation or desire to save the world is also not as clear as it might be. In the book he has a long sequence about his life story in which all this becomes clear and in the process illustrates his own character. In the film there is a short sequence in which he describes some of this to a collection of powerful and rather grumpy business men which then leads into the exciting assassination sequence. As such an important part of the plot there simply isn't enough time spent on Veidt to really get to grips with the man and his role in the world of the Watchmen.

Silk Spectre II is eye wateringly beautiful and her scenes powerfully reminded me how sexy stockings and suspenders are. This is not a film you want to give away as a prize at Sunday School when its out on DVD. The fight scenes throughout are brutal and in particular the scene where Nite Owl and Silk Spectre II are attacked in an alley showed just what fighting someone with the skills and strength of a Batman would really be like. The fighting is of a fairly straightforward style but highly satisfactory with the emphasis on speed and strength rather than exotic or flamboyant moves. It is a perfect depiction of comic book violence with realistic results.

Visually it is a stunning production. There is an interesting interplay between realistic, cluttered sets and colourful superhero costumes all combined with comic book style framing of shots. Archimedes, Nite Owl's airship, looks wonderful and at times the style of it all almost looks over produced. Doctor Manhattan is stunning to see, although on a few, very minor, occasions, his computer graphic overlay did look a little artificial. The scene where he blows up the tank comes to mind; the movement of the arm is just a shade unreal. But this aside he has been successfully brought to the big screen. I was surprised at the choice to make him glow which is not something that is apparent from the comic book representation. The Watchmen's only true superhero is cleverly used where the plot diverges from the book.

Doctor Manhattan of course has his big revelation on Mars and these sequences were really some of those that needed to be longer to have the required dramatic impact. Mars reminded me of the planet landings from the original Star Trek which, wonderful though they sometimes looked, often could never quite escape the studio bound atmosphere. There simply wasn't time enough for sufficient Martian grandeur or for Laurie's breakdown at her personal revelation or at Doctor Manhattan's re-affirmation of his interest in life. Thankfully Doctor Manhattan's origin sequence was wonderfully put together into a stirring sequence about the creation of a man made god.

Another striking thing about this film is the use of music. It's a film about the twentieth century and as a result has a very twentieth century soundtrack to it. The opening titles use Bob Dylan to good effect; in many ways this is one of the most successful parts of the whole film. Occasionally the use of this music seems incongruous and I couldn't help finding the love (or rather sex) scene between Nite Owl and Silk Spectre II in the owlship rather laughable especially with its use of the original version of "Hallelujah" as backing.

At nearly three hours though it is a long, long film in accordance with the trend for some years now of lengthy productions. And despite myself, I could not help but notice the story lurch and seemingly stop at various points. For a film about such action packed characters, it was rather slow in parts. It reminded me sometimes of my reaction when watching Batman Returns; whilst I loved the production values, actually following the film occasionally induced a rather awkward, glum feeling brought on by its strange pacing. It was like being on a roller coaster where the ups and down were horribly mis-timed. This, it felt, was symptomatic of simply trying to fit too much into the time allowed.

And speaking of Batman, it's interesting to compare this film with another recent superhero film, The Dark Knight. Christopher Nolan's production is overall a more consistent affair. In it, he manages the virtually impossible task of making Batman seem almost plausible in a contemporary setting. This is a film of course that is, unlike Watchmen, built from the ground up and purely within the parameters of cinematic construction. The Batman of Dark Knight is, to my mind, rather different from the one of the comics. In it, Christian Bale's Batman is starting out on a road that will eventually lead him to Robo-Cop or Iron Man. In making him almost plausible, The Dark Knight distorts the classic mysterious detective of the comics into a technological hero who only works through his gadgetry. Its success is taking the real world (or at least a rather grim and nasty imitation thereof) and trying to fit Batman into it.

Zack Snyder could have taken this approach with Watchmen and indeed there are stories that the movie studios wanted him to set it in a contemporary period with Doctor Manhattan being asked to intervene in Iraq. He could have pruned the plot right down to its essentials and not included the beautiful sections with the original Silk Spectre, Mothman and so forth and given us a somewhat stale, anodyne modern interpretation. Bravely he stood up for his love of the source material and took up the far larger challenge of trying to create the whole world of the Watchmen.

To film the unfilmable Watchmen was always going to be a challenging feat for even a superheroic producer. Thankfully, as someone who has read and re-read Watchmen continually ever since popping into Smith's one early weekday morning in 1987 to buy it, my view is that Zack Snyder really has brought it's vision to the screen in a gorgeous, powerful production. I hope somewhere he is having his Ozymandias "I DID IT!" moment.

It's still difficult to tell whether I was happy that the movie was over, or if I thought it was a good movie.

The great masterpiece of comic books by Alan Moore and Dave Gibbons "Watchmen": the great revolution of comics in the 80's giving the world a darker and mature vision of "Heroes", can truly be  Zack Snyder's masterpiece.
Zack, with the help of David Hayter and Alex Tse (writers) could bring "Watchmen" to the big screen in an impressive way. The story of 12 chapters, about a world where superheroes really exist since 1930, all of them taking as inspiration the hero Superman. Each with their own abilities and "powers". In this world, the U.S. won the Vietnam War thanks to Dr. Manhattan (Billy Crudup) the most powerful of all heroes, powers to controls the atoms (this means he control everything), he is considered by world's popullation one true God. After that and the third re-election to the presidency of Nixon, the police begins to strike and civil unrest against masked vigilantes. With that Nixon is forced to sign the Keene Act in 1977 which consisted of all "costumed adventurers" to register with the government. With this most vigilantes decided to retire, some revealing their secret identities mostly to win cash thanks to the media's attention, that was the case of Adrian Veidt (Matthew Goode), the "Ozymandias." Others, such as "Comedian" (Jeffrey Dean Morgan) and "Dr. Manhattan", continued to work under the supervision and control of the government. The vigilante known as Rorschach (Jackie Earle Haley), however, has operated as a renegade hero and out-of-law, frequently pursued by police.
Years passed and the cold war ravaging the world, "The Comedian" (the hero most despised of all) is found dead in his house, having his secret identity being revealed. This draws attention to Rorschach begins contacting his former colleagues for clues, considering almost everyone as possible suspects.
All 12 chapters were transported in an impressive way to the cinema, the Adaptation of Snyder is fantastic and can be very loyal to the comic. The entire cast was perfectly chosen for the heroes, all with excellent performances, but who stands out for me is Jackie Earle Haley as Rorschach. He was always my favorite character and the film also manages to show me this, Rorschach is more BADASS than ever was, as the movie it-self, not only Badass (as most of Snyder's movies) but it manages to be the best adaptation from a comic to the screen ever made!

"Watchmen" was not my favorite superhero movie.  In fact, I couldn't really get into it at all.  I was warned that I should read the graphic novel before seeing the film and now I see why.  While Superman and Batman have been included in pop culture for a long time, this film made me realize how little of the DC Comic universe I am familiar with and how different it is than the Marvel universe that has dominated cinema over the past fifteen years.  "Watchmen" just doesn't "feel" like other superhero films and it is not supposed to.  Right away, I liked that the heroes do not have super powers and that they were just average people trying to make the world a better place amidst the Cold War.  Granted, that was spoiled when a gigantic blue character came into the picture, but their inclusion in a warped 1980's New York City was pretty cool.  The concept had a lot of promise and, maybe my mistake was watching the 3+ hour Director's Cut, but my excitement for "Watchmen" ended there.  Rorschach was really cool but his voice reminded me of Batman (the Christian Bale edition) too much, Nite Owl II (played by Patrick Wilson who is awesome) visually reminded me of Batman so I was kind of sad when I realized that it wasn't Batman, and Dr. Manhattan didn't remind me of Batman at all but he just didn't fit in with the rest of the characters.  That's where I lost interest - I feel like the movie would've been great without Dr. Manhattan but since most of the plot revolved around him, I couldn't ignore him and enjoy the story.  I'm sure that if I was familiar with the graphic novel, I would like him a lot more but I just couldn't form any sort of attachment to this large smurf.  The special effects are awesome, the cinematography gives the film a really dark feel, and the violence is portrayed beyond what we want to see (circular saw + arms = no cutaway... well in a sense there WAS a cutaway...), but unless you are already interested in this group of heroes, I don't think that this movie will make you a fan.

The movie made me want to read the graphic novel, not the other way round. I like the whole idea of it. How these are superheros with very real, even criminal, flaws, I love the cinematography and camera work. I love the music chosen and the references to 80s pop culture. I had a few qualms with some of the acting but other than that, I thoroughly enjoyed this.
visually stunning, beautifully told. Zack Snyder makes a masterpiece in my opinion and I believe this to be the greatest superhero film to date.

For Zack Snyder's effort to adapt heavily philosophical and dense graphic novel by Alan Moore and Dave Gibbons, this movie deserves 5/5. Trailer is intriguing but the movie left out many details that make the original source great. Nonetheless actors are fabulous in their roles especially Billy Crudup and Jackie Earle Haley. Boy, talk about missing the point. Snyder's slick, stylistic flourishes and gleeful, cartoonish acts of violence are so contrary to the script, it is truly baffling. The story is kick-started by an existential crisis suffered by humanity when faced with the existence of a God-like being. This story cannot make a lick of sense if the "regular people" behave in a superhuman fashion, and that's exactly what Snyder provides. There is a just a complete lack of understanding here. I feel especially bad about Matthew Goode. Here's a fine actor placed in a sorely misdirected role that does not work in any way-- the character is portrayed from the very start in a dark, humorless, villainous fashion, when the text itself suggests Ozymandias is a heroic, inspiring, likeable figure. It's bad, bad directing.

Watchmen is the long-awaited graphic novel adaptation that has for a long time been deemed un-filmable. There have been many different points over the years where this movie was supposed to be made, which always ended up not happening. But now Watchmen is finally here in all its glory, and it's probably the best adaptation possible of this complex graphic novel. Much credit to Zack Snyder who turned this graphic novel that was deemed un-filmable at many points by many people, into the visually stunning masterpiece it is. 

The story takes place in an alternative 1985, with Nixon beginning his third term as president, and the streets of New York are gritty, dark, and violent. The story revolves around mystery and the conspiracy that follows the murder of one Edward Blake, former masked-hero The Comedian, while the backstory deals with the threat of nuclear war and global destruction that could be caused by the Cold War opposing superpowers, Russia and the United States.

Masked vigilante Rorschach, who's the only one still operating after the Keene Act had made the masked heroisms illegal, believes that someone is picking off costumed heroes to begin their own agenda of destruction. Rorschach begins investigating and hunting down the person that is responsible for The Comedian's death. As he continues his investigation we meet Dr. Manhattan, a physicist-turned-godlike being and Laurie (Silk Spectre II).
Jon Osterman was a scientist who was tragically trapped in a scientific test chamber and blown away down to the atom but came back as a Godly-being that is Dr. Manhattan. He is the only character in the story that has an actual super-power. 
As for Laurie she lives with her boyfriend, Dr. Manhattan in a government protected laboratory/home. Since she has retired from adventuring (as they called it in the graphic novel) she now tries to live a normal life she can never have because of Jon himself. In turn of events she goes to a friend of hers, Daniel Dreiberg, who also happens to be a former masked-hero, Nite Owl II. 
Meanwhile Ozymandias, now retired, has become a billionaire and dubbed "the smartest man on the planet".
These main six characters plus the tons of great supporting characters intertwine in the story that is more complex than any other film I've watched,. Any attempt to describe the complex plot of this movie would be nearly impossible.

Watchmen was an extremely complex graphic novel filled with a lot of flawed costumed characters, strong plot, powerful sense of style, and also contained a world that seems a little too close to our own. The movie carries every one of these elements in the best way it possibly could. It stays true to the novel, and only changes a few details including the much-debated ending.

The memorable characters are very well portrayed and acted as well. Dr. Manhattan (the giant blue guy) is played very well by Billy Crudup, who manages to keep the character interesting despite his emotionless attitude. Patrick Wilson (Night Owl II), and Matthew Goode (Ozymandias) are also very good in their roles. Malin Akerman (Silk Spectre II) is probably the only actor in the film that hasn't done the job good enough in my opinion. Her character suffers in everything from the emotions or lack-thereof, the character just felt so soulless. 
However the two actors that truly help add depth and a real sense of anger and judgment to the film are Jeffrey Dean Morgan as The Comedian, and Jackie Earle Haley as Rorschach. Rorschach is my favourite character, Not only because he's the coolest but also technically he's not really a hero at all. He's a psychopath anti-hero with harmful and destructive behaviour, even though in a way he's trying to do what he believes is right for the world. He is a fascinating character. The Way he sees the world, his moral judgment is what mirrors his constantly shifting ink blot mask. A World where Justice and Evil are the two opposites without the silver lining. 

The main six characters plus the supporting and even the small characters (Bernie) are different point of view of the world and the society.

In-short:

Ozymandias: Adrian believes the humanity is headed to a nuclear war and an eventual annihilation so he does everything to prevent it, even if it means sacrificing millions of people along the way. 

Dr. Manhattan: Since he has become the superpowered being he is, he's become detached from humanity, so he does not see a point in saving humanity at all.

The Comedian: He believes that humans are savage in nature, and that civilization can never be more than an idea. He therefore chooses to become a mockery of society, fighting and killing without reservation.

Silk Spectre II: As she is the only leading female character in the story, she is the emotional core of the story. 

Nite Owl II: The Batman of the story of sorts. He is intelligent, caring and most ordinary of the six. Had a tragic childhood and believes he must do the right thing, learning and taking the mantle from the first Nite Owl. 

Rorschach: The Moral compass of the story, the main leading character for my point of view. His moral judgment leads to the events of Watchmen to unleash. He sees the world as set of black-and-white values that take many shapes but never mix into shades of grey, similar to the ink blot tests of his namesake. Rorschach sees existence as random and this viewpoint leaves the character "free to 'scrawl his own design' on a 'morally blank world'.

With the dazzling score and the perfect choices for the soundtracks were just few of the great things in this film to mention. The dark and gritty visual style that comes from Zack Snyder couldn't have been better. With the opening scene of the Ultimate cut going back a few decades from the story to set-up the story and the world its in really good. The Black Freighter, Gerard Butler voiced animated story goes in-n-out during the film, paralleling the story as it goes.

This is a great film that stays true to the original graphic novel while transitioning its style, characters, chain of events, and storyline from page-to-screen the best it possibly could. However if you're not familiar with the graphic novel it might be hard to understand many elements in the film, and be left confused. These characters are not as famous as those types of household name characters, and may be hard for someone's whose never read the novel to understand. Personally I've read the graphic novel twice in as many years, and I thought the movie was incredible and true to the novel except for few parts that I could live with the change. I always give a movie props for not taking the easy way out by spoon-feeding everything to the audience. The book, as well as the movie, was daring by taking of the risk of being complex and making you think for a change. Watchmen is a great movie, and despite its long running time of 215 minutes, I never found it boring at all. Watchmen is a fascinating graphic novel adaptation that deserves to be seen by anybody that likes their movies complex, dark, and absorbing.

Personally I love the film so much I had to watch it at least twice in the last month's time to make sure I don't miss anything for the review. 

Personal rating of the film: 9/10

PS. I recommend you to watch the Ultimate Cut, also to read the 12 issues graphic novel that the film was based on. You won't be disappointed, I can assure you.

I decided to rewrite my review of this movie. Because I realized I was wrong in giving this movie only 2 stars. I originally disliked this movie because I thought it was boring and lacking in action sequences. And one reason I really hated this movie was because I thought most of the heroes in this movie were monstrous and selfish. And I realize now that maybe that was one of the points that was to be realized about this movie. It lets us look at super heroes that may have saved the day on more than one occasion, but despite their heroic deeds they're just as messed up and just as evil as the criminals they've put away. This point was proven true in the scene when the comedian tried to rape one of his team-mates on the original watchmen team. And while the movie itself was boring I realize that I was wrong to judge it by it's entertainment value and forgot to judge it as a character study of sorts. I think that this movie has some value because it broke the mold of the super hero genre that nobody has done well except in the movie Chronicle. Zack Snyder is a really annoying director, but I can't deny anymore he made one hell of a movie.

Alrighty, so it's not the perfect end all Watchmen adaptation.  I've read the graphic novel like five times and every time I read it I read it differently or find something new, this was pretty much like giving it another read.  A new angle to observe these watchful men.  There are certain things that you just can't translate and it fails to capture that same oh-so-clever deep subject matter.  I just didn't get the same blissfulness that I got the first time I read the novel.  Now with that being said, this movie is epic in the greatest sense of the term.  For a story that many described as unadaptable, Snyder's huge ambition was a huge success.  The main thing he had to capture here was the characters and he did it great justice.  Nite Owl and Rorschach were perfect.  Nite Owl is such a sad and sympathetic guy and Patrick Wilson really becomes the role and Jackie Hayley as Rorschach was such an odd and amazing choice; very inspired casting.  The visuals were incredible, the opening title sequence rocks (like REALLY rocks), the soundtrack was unbelievable.  It was a great movie going experience.  I will say that to the uninitiated you should get familiar with the story line before going in cause it might be a bit confusing.  It's set in an alternate 1985 during the Cold War where Nixon is reelected president.  The violence is extreme.  Bloody and cringe inducing violence that goes so far over the top.  It's got lots of flashbacks and scene jumping and a ton of deep meaningful dialogue.  Speaking of dialogue, the acting was great especially when dealing with a script that was basically written in 1985 even though some of the delivery seems hammy or phony so just remember that.  Just hearing some of the words aloud, setting scenes to already incredible songs, and just seeing some of the signature slow mo action for so many memorable scenes was so insanely cool.  It's a smart and original film.  You won't see anything like it even after all of the influence the novel has created, the story and characters are still there own.
While not a typical comic book action flick, Watchmen offers an interesting look into superhero life and has many redeeming qualities that wont leave fans of the landmark graphic novel disappointed.

It stands for: it don't mind how mediochre your work be, for the strength of the original will make it look great. But experience has taught me about this little trick. Anyway, this is a contemporary visionary artwork on advanced cg multi-layered cinematics, and it makes a worthy attempt to preserve the thoughtfulness of the original graphic novel in its script. Excellent roles. Anyway, it doesn't stop misunderstanding pretty much the adaptation concept. Thus, this film is nothing but somehting similar to make an adaptation of Orson Welles' C. Kane as a short pulp magazine story with big onomatopeias. It is paradoxically both excellent and phoney.

I loved this movie.  It's similar to (though less restrained and barely not as good as) the rebooted Batman franchise.  It's dark, violent, talky, plot-oriented, and morally ambiguous, all of which add to its brilliance.  You do not HAVE to be familiar with the source material for it to be an awesome movie.  I can testify, as I have never read the highly acclaimed graphic novel and still loved the film.  It's long, but not boring, and the dialogue is fantastic.  Rorshach, in particular, is an amazing character.  The beauty of this film is that the storyteller takes a handful of seriously flawed characters who have to work together to overcome an opponent which is more powerful than them all, all of which is in the backdrop of a nuclear war.  The plot twists are often and jaw-dropping, and by the end, your jaw will be widened even further.  It is a fantastic ending to a fantastic film.  I cannot recommend it more.

Watching Watchmen is a plastic and sterile experience.  Disappointing and surprising, since I'm a big fan of the Allan Moore comic (he took his name off the film, but then he never wanted a film in the first place.)

Even though the digitial whiz yet story-challenged  Zack Snyder is very true to the source story and the visuals (the comic is more or less a faithful storyboard for the film), that may be exactly what's wrong with this thing.  The whole thing feels airless and dry and also suffers from some weak casting in at least two key roles.

Watchmen is a dystopian take on post cold war America, one in which self appointed superheroes have captured the public's imagination after WWII (Minutemen), then been banned, then a resurgance in the sixties with a new group (The Watchmen), who lose the favour of the authorities and are banned once again.   The U.S. has won the Vietnam war and is lording over the Soviets in the cold war  (thanks to the iconic character Dr. Manhattan, a godlike victim of a radiation overdose) . As Richard Nixon is on to his fourth term, the story is a meditation on the American dream, the disillusionment of the sixties, the role of vigilantes and super heroes and how they are coopted by the powers that be, and many many other complicated themes and story points,   All of them are crammed into the film and as a result, we have very superficial character development and perfunctory and cold action scenes. 

I'm more and more convinced that good film versions of complex literature, even comics in this case, require the filmmaker to select one or two simple ideas and explore them rather than trying to capture every philosophical theme and minute plot point.  This problem was almost identical in Moore's V for Vendetta adaptation.  I know there's also a fear of the geeky fans not approving, especially with a property with armies of nerdy fans, who for some reason have the power to scuttle a film franchise.  

On the plus side of performances, Jackie Earle Haley is an excellent Rorschak, an obsessive and weasly (and mostly masked) performance, Jeffery Dean Morgan is a macho and charismatic Comedian, it's a shame he doesn't get more screen time, and even with all the CG, Billy Crudup (and his digital doppelganger as Dr. Manhattan) are mezmerizing to watch.  Carla Gugino, excellent in everything, ages four decades here and is wonderful as ex-superhero and mother of the Silk Spectre.  Patrick Wilson does fine as the nerdy geek Night Owl.

On the down side, Malin Ackerman is incredibly wooden as the Silk Spectre (Dr. Manhattan's love interest) a shame, because I usually enjoy her in comedies and she's beautiful, Matthew Goode falls completely flat as super genius and ambiguous hero Ozymandius, which brings the film down because his role is pivotal. 

Also on the down side is the too obvious on the nose choice of musical tracks from the era, Dylan's "Times They are A-changing' for the protest sixties stuff and Leonard Cohen's 'Hallelujah' for a bad sex scene with Night Owl and Silk Specter in a rocket ship.

All that said, the film is almost three hours long but goes by quite quickly due to fun visuals, some very memorable lines, all lifted right out of Moore's orignal book, and lots of cheesy fun here and there.  Okay for a rainy Sunday for something that's cool enough to watch with teens.

An excellent quality comic book adaption that is very faithful to source material as well as not your average hero film. Zack Snyder brings forth a dark and gruesome image of a very dark and haunting 1980's era New York. The film is action packed, at times blends in dark humour but is always deep,and charismatic.

The Watchmen are not your everyday superheroes you see such as Superman or Batman. These guys are outsiders, no body likes them, nobody wants them. They are significantly darker in terms of style and morals. The film has a great plot filled with deception, and chaos also the threat of pending war. I loved the blend of real world items of past such as the Cold War and the thick grasp it had during this time. The film was great and pure story from start to finish.

The heroes (more of vigilantes) are great Rorschach is menacing, brutal, intimidating and ultimately realistic. He is the detective and the one whom uncovers the dramatic plot caused by former ally Ozymandias. Nite Owl played by Patrick Wilson was also great and had some good chemistry with Silk Spector even though that "air ship" scene was unnecessary. However its Dr. Manhattan that gives you a mixed response, he's so powerful he can do wonders to help or also he's so powerful he can kill us all. He invokes a great reaction and is also accurate to source material, textbook super powered being. Snyder shot this film great with its angles and dark imagery as well as its various bright tones and over the top sequences. Watchmen is a true comic book world come to life but not one you've ever seen and one that works, one that works very well. DC and WB finally crafted a great hero movie that didn't have Batman or Superman attached to it.

When I first saw this movie I was frankly very impressed. Then I bought, and read the comic, and realised that Zach must have one of the easiest jobs in the world. Creatively bankrupt asshole that he is. He does have a knack/flair for style though, and for making virtual carbon copies of each of the comic book panels he feeds like a vampire from. This may be a technical challenge, but it sure as shit isn't a creative one. On a personal level this gets 1 star. This is the kind of shit that destroys cinema. He makes copies. He's a a piece of modern assholed technology. There's not a creative element in his composition. He makes copies. He is a cultural scanner/printer. You could probably write a program that makes ZS movies. Step1. Locate a well loved Comic Step2. Literally make a live action copy of every single panel. Step3 Make some VERY SLIGHT changes to some panels, typically from the end panels, where its more noticeable, and therefore likely to come off as 'creative input'. Step 4. Create (and this the hard part) an opening credit sequence, but stylize it as a music video, and which really is, a music video (and boy they're really hard to make aren't they boys and girls???). Comics may look like storyboards, but in all actuality, they're really not, and if you cant be a big boy and make a TRANSLATION of the source material into YOUR OWN interpretation, then whats the point?? I mean shit, what's even really left at the end of the day???? 300 is a classic example. That movie was shit. It wasn't ok, it was SHIT. It wasn't even mildly ok, it was SHIT and nothing but SHIT!!! Why? Because the comic was SHIT, and the movie is a carbon copy of the historically offensive comic; only its even more offensive since the 'changes' Zach made, where actually just additional micro-scenes involving the depiction of creatures that did not, and never have existed. FM only had humans in the comic, no monsters, supernatural beings etc. Although it's such a retarded comic that is understandable that Zach thought supernatural elements and monsters where implied in some scenes.

Science-fiction comic book fantasy, the gratuitous violence of which made the movie experience unenjoyable for me. So it failed to entertain me. Most of it's over-exaggerated violence is directed at criminals, it was unnecessary to drive in a point. There's also a lot of nudity and language, so this really isn't a family-movie or a 'superhero movie for kids'. Its brutality, profanity and cruelty aside, the storyline wouln't have gone bad without the film's over-extended duration. Only slightly corny, the movie has some thought-provoking moments which provoked a thought about justice and how society lets it's worst criminals get away too easily. The real danger of nuclear weapons may be unclear for someone who was not born in the 80's. 
The martial arts acts had bone-crunching scenes, but they were well designed and lots of them were central to what happened in the story. Much of the worst violence took place outside the martial arts fights. Much of the action in the movie is simply gratuitous violence practiced on defenseless individuals, however, which seemed to me to have no purpose whatsoever except perhaps to cause nausea. The other problem with the movie in addition to its violence was its lenght, which occasionally made it seem boring and repetitive.
 The film is saved from being totally spoiled by its ultraviolence because of a few of its grand visions. I'm referring to Dr. Manhattan's words on the surface of Mars to The Silk Spectre. The part about Mars and the value of life and the part about 'oxygen having turned into gold' were very inventive and cool. 
There is also a moment where the heroes enter the bad guy's palace, or tower, in antarctica, and a rock adaptation of "All along the watchtower" starts to play. The music is well done.
 Wonderful details, and one could notice that much attention had been paid. All the special effects were awesome, and I would be amiss to say that they didn't save much of the movie experience.
Kudos also for Rorshach's 'Batmanlike'-voice and the beautiful Silk Spectre, bads for the absolutely ridiculous rubber mask that is supposed to be president Nixon's face. Special effects, Silk Spectre, philosophical musings, galactic visions and just uncompromising attitude saved the movie from dismal failure caused by most violent scenes I have ever seen in any film. Had there been much less excessive violence, and had the movie been a bit shorter, I would have rated it five stars. Now, the movie will have to settle for three stars from this reviewer.
Dark and compelling, recreates the tension of the cold war, whilst being true to the source material.
JACKIE EARLE HALEY MAKES THIS MOVIE!
Phenomenal.  But not for everybody.

Considering the restrictions in the medium, 'Watchmen' is a gigantic triumph.  It's just as engaging as reading the graphic novel for the first time.  This is probably one of the most overwhelming movie experience I've ever had.
Boring didn't like at all
It was so not a good movie.
love the  graphic novel love the movie.
Interesting at first, but drags on too long. Far too much CGI for my tastes too.
Dreadful. Suuuuure it looks sparkly, but the acting is shocking and it's a disgrace to the source material.
1st read the graphic novel 20 years ago, awesome cant wait
Had no idea what to expect, but I ended up liking it a lot more than I thought I would.

One of the most underated films, let alone most underrated comic book adaptation, any film that can combine dark brutality and deep storyline and having a character that can do anything is a winner in my books. Its absolutely nothing like the typical super hero blockbuster, the music choice is a lot like that of Quentin Tarintino films, which is a complement in itself, and the presentation of the film keeps you glued to it through it's entirety. Director Zack Snyder ( sorry if I spelled it wrong ) is the reason I want to see Man of Steel in 2013, if he can do for superman, who I am not a great fan of, what he did for watchmen, man of steel is definitely one to watch! Watchmen... 5 stars!
I didn't even notice the 3 hrs and I never read the comic, just don't take kids . . . wow, blue guy is HUGE!!!
Zach Snyder sticks to the book and gives instant gratification.  It's an anti-superhero movie.
I couldn't wait to see this, it's a must see.

The unfilmable comic book inevitably would be unviewable by most people. The themes underlying the action are not typical for a "superhero" flick and can't deliver on the level of action that people anticipated. Nonetheless, there should be kudos for the film makers in making an honest try of it and doing quite well albeit with a very dark camera setting that adds to the mystery for those not in the know.
Much better than it could of been but much worse than it should've been. If you liked the book then whether you like this is a 50/50 shot.
the most underrated movie ever, I liked everything about it.
This movie was looonnggg as HECK! I fell asleep, woke up, went to the bathroom got more pop corn and it seemed as if I did not miss a thing. It got good at the end like most action movies do.
I really enjoyed this movie. A lot of politics behind a group of vigilante super heros. Dark and violent balanced with love and compassion.

This film was truly an EPIC. not as great as the movie becuase it wasn't as thought provoking but doesn't mean it wasn't a great film. it was different because there weren't that many action scenes, but the action was gorey and beautifully cinematic.
A wonderful adaptation of a classic Graphic Novel.

The movie is merely a precise copy of what is already illustrated in the comic book novel, just animated from panel to panel.  Even so, I found the movie a little more tasteless than the book, and personally got much more out of reading it than seeing the film.  I suppose it gets some points for being faithful to the original, but then I wonder why they bothered to make a film at all if the visual comic book already accomplished what was necessary and what already worked so well.

I speak as a fan of the graphic novel, but I loved it.
Very much captured the spirit of the book and held my attention for the full running time. Plan to see this a few more times in the cinema.
Long movie but overall really good.
Rorshach was awesome.

First off, it takes nearly two hours to tell everyone's story in what could've taken MAYBE a half an hour. Then, the director of the 'Dawn of the Dead' remake and '300' decides to make it dull as shit telling it. And if that weren't enough, he made it end so anticlimactically, it's a wonder why I decide to rate it as high as I am...

A great super hero movie. I watch it over and over again . I love this movie so much
The dark, gritty side of super-hero films, dependent on its character acting and Snyder's gloomy atmosphere.
Good movie, but a little weird and long.
Quite possibly the longest superhero movie ever, and the story and atmosphere is very true to the graphic novel that it is based on.

I guess I'm not sure why they waited so long to make this film.   The CGI stuff, though highly entertaining, didn't add anything to the characterization or narrative--this movie could have been made 15 years ago without the high octane special effects and been much more effectively done and definitely more relevent, if that's what the filmmaker was going for.  

I was bored whenever Rorshach or the Comedian weren't on-screen but I really enjoyed the opening credits - very inventive, nostalgic, and playful.  Also, I do like the idea of flawed heros, but this theme has been done to death in countless superhero flicks over the past 5 years or so.

Overall, very entertaining, but unevenly paced, overlong and has a few too many endings.  If the filmmaker cut out about 30 mins - especially the scenes invoving Nite Owl and Silk Spectre, or any of the Dr. Manhattan dangling manparts (way too distracting), I'd be tempted to rate this 4 start or higher.  As it is, I rate this....
